(Ord. 424, 9-25-2018, eff. 10-1-2018)
3-3A-2: PAYMENT REQUIRED AND PENALTY:
   A.   Any State licensee originally entering upon any occupation herein
listed shall pay the tax therefor at the Office of City Clerk on or before the
date upon which he enters upon such occupation. Said licensee shall provide a
copy of a current State license before payment of an Occupation Tax will be
accepted. Thereafter, the licensee shall pay the tax annually on or before the
first day of April now and through October 31, 2019. Effective November 1,
2019, the licensee shall pay the tax annually on or before the first day of
November.
   B.   The Occupation Tax subject to this section shall be prorated on a
monthly basis for the year in which an occupation began operations.
   C.   Upon payment of the said Occupation Tax, the City Clerk shall issue a
receipt to said State licensee, which said licensee shall post in a conspicuous
place on the occupation premises to exhibit that said licensee is permitted by
the City to enter upon such occupation on said premises.
   D.   Any person who engages in any of the occupations taxed by this article
without paying said Occupation Tax imposed therefor in advance of such
operation, is guilty of an offense against the City, and upon conviction
thereof shall be fined the sum of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00),
excluding costs. Each day of such violation shall constitute a separate
offense. (Ord. 424, 9-25-2018, eff. 10-1-2018)
3-3A-3: ANNUAL REPORT:
The City Clerk shall make an annual report to the ABLE Commission, covering the
fiscal year, showing the number and class of licensees subject to the
Occupation Tax and the amount of money collected from said tax. (Ord. 424, 9-
25-2018, eff. 10-1-2018)
3-3A-4: HOURS OF OPERATION:
No establishment to which the mixed beverage or on premises beer and wine
Occupational Tax is applicable, nor any agent, servant or employee of such
establishment shall sell, dispense, serve or allow to be consumed any mixed
beverages, beer or wine on the premises between the hours of two o'clock (2:00)
A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. (Ord. 424, 9-25-2018, eff. 10-1-2018)
3-3A-5: EMPLOYMENT:
No person shall employ any person under eighteen (18) years of age in the
selling of beer or wine or employ any person under twenty one (21) years of age
in the selling of spirits. Provided that:
   A.   A mixed beverage, beer and wine, caterer, public event, special event,
bottle club, retail wine or retail beer licensee may employ servers or sales
clerks who are at least eighteen (18) years of age, except persons under twenty
one (21) years of age may not serve in designated bar or lounge areas; and
   B.   A mixed beverage, beer and wine, caterer, public event, special event
or bottle club licensee may employ or hire musical bands who have musicians who
are under eighteen (18) years of age if each such musician is either
accompanied by a parent or legal guardian or has in their person, to be made
available for inspection upon demand by any employee of the ABLE Commission or
law enforcement officer, a written, notarized affidavit from the parent or
legal guardian giving the underage musician permission to perform in designated
bar or lounge areas. (Ord. 424, 9-25-2018, eff. 10-1-2018)
3-3A-6: MIXED BEVERAGE/CATERER COMBINATION PERMIT:
A mixed beverage/caterer combination Occupational Tax permit shall authorize
the holder thereof to purchase or sell mixed beverages as specified by law for
the holder of a mixed beverage license or a caterer license. A separate permit
shall be required for each place of business. Prior to obtaining a City
Occupational Tax permit, a mixed beverage/caterer combination license must be
issued by the Alcoholic Beverage Laws Enforcement Commission. (Ord. 424, 9-25-
2018, eff. 10-1-2018)
3-3A-7: SPECIAL EVENT TEMPORARY PERMIT:
A special event temporary permit may be issued to an organization, association,
or nonprofit corporation organized for political, fraternal, charitable,
religious or social purposes. The holder of a special event temporary permit is
authorized to sell and distribute alcoholic beverage on the premises for which
the permit is issued. A special event temporary permit shall be valid for a
period not to exceed ten (10) consecutive days, and no qualified organization
may obtain more than one such permit in a 90-day period. Prior to obtaining a
City Occupational Tax permit, a special event license must be issued by the
Alcoholic Beverage Laws Enforcement Commission. (Ord. 424, 9-25-2018, eff. 10-
1-2018)
3-3A-8: BREWERIES AND BREWPUBS:
   A.   No person shall operate or maintain a brewery or brewpub without having
previously paid the Occupational Tax as provided in this article.
   B.   No brewery or brewpub to which the brewery or brewpub Occupational Tax
is applicable, nor any agent, servant or employee of such establishment shall
sell, dispense, serve or allow to be consumed any beer, as that term is defined
in 37A Oklahoma Statutes section 1-103(5), on the premises between the hours of
two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. (Ord. 424, 9-25-2018, eff.
10-1-2018)
3-3A-9: CHARITABLE AUCTION OR CHARITABLE ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE EVENT:
   A.   A charitable organization exempt from taxation under title 26 of
section 501(c)(3), (4), (5), (7), (8), (9), (10), or (19) of the United States
Internal Revenue Code shall be permitted to conduct a charitable auction or
alcoholic beverage event. The sponsor of the event must hold a charitable
auction or charitable alcoholic beverage event license as required by 37A
Oklahoma Statutes section 2-129, pay the City Occupational Tax as provided in
this article, and conform to all requirements of State law and this Code. The
charitable alcoholic beverage event Occupational Tax permit shall authorize the
holder thereof to conduct a wine, spirit and/or beer event which may consist of
one or more of a wine, spirit and/or beer-tasting event, a wine, spirit and/or
beer dinner event or a wine, spirit and/or beer auction, which may be either a
live auction conducted by an auctioneer or a silent auction for which:
      1.   Bid sheets are accepted from interested bidders at the event;
      2.   The holders of tickets are allowed to bid online for a period not
exceeding thirty (30) days prior to the event; or
      3.   Both bid sheets are accepted at the event and online bids are
accepted pursuant to subsection A2 of this section.
   B.   A charitable alcoholic beverage event shall be conducted solely to
raise funds for charitable purposes. A charitable alcoholic beverage
Occupational Tax permit shall allow the event attendees access to tastings,
samples, dinners and alcoholic beverages as parts of their entrance fee or
ticket price. Wine, spirits and/or beer used in, served or consumed at a
charitable alcoholic beverage event may be purchased by the charitable
organization or donated by any person or entity.
   C.   The charitable alcoholic beverage event Occupational Tax permit shall
allow the event to be held for a period not exceeding four (4) days. Only one
such Occupational Tax permit may be issued to an organization in any twelve-
month period. The charitable organization holding a charitable alcoholic
beverage event Occupational Tax permit shall not be required to obtain a
special event license.
   D.   Charitable auction and charitable alcoholic beverage event Occupational
Tax permit holders may also utilize a State-licensed caterer to provide
additional alcohol services at the event and on the premises. The State-
licensed caterer shall be required to obtain a special event Occupational Tax
permit from the City.
   E.   The charitable auction Occupational Tax permit shall authorize the
holder thereof to auction wine, spirits and/or beer purchased from a retail
package store or received as a gift from an individual if the auction is
conducted to raise funds for charitable purposes. The charitable auction
Occupational Tax permit shall be issued for a period not to exceed two (2)
days. Only two (2) such Occupational Tax permits shall be issued to an
organization in any twelve-month period. The maximum amount of wine, spirits
and/or beer auctioned pursuant to the charitable auction Occupational Tax
permit shall not exceed fifty (50) gallons. All wines, beer and spirits
auctioned pursuant to the charitable auction Occupational Tax permit shall be
registered and all fees and taxes shall be paid in accordance with the Oklahoma
Alcoholic Beverage Control Act.
   F.   No charitable alcoholic beverage event Occupational Tax permit shall be
required for an organization, association or nonprofit corporation which is an
economic development chamber or similar entity, provided the event is not
conducted primarily for fundraising purposes, and provided the services of a
State- licensed caterer are used to provide and distribute the alcoholic
beverages at the event. The State-licensed caterer shall be required to obtain
a special event Occupational Tax permit from the City. (Ord. 424, 9-25-2018,
eff. 10-1-2018)
3-3A-10: PERSONS UNDER TWENTY ONE YEARS OF AGE NOT TO BE ADMITTED TO CERTAIN
LOUNGE OR BAR AREAS:
If the premises of a licensee of the ABLE Commission contains a separate or
enclosed lounge or bar area, which has as its main purpose the sale or
distribution of alcoholic beverages for on- premises consumption,
notwithstanding that as an incidental service, meals or short order foods are
made available therein, no person under twenty one (21) years of age shall be
admitted to such area, except for members of a musical band employed or hired
as provided in subsection
3-3A-5B of this article when the band is to perform within such area, or
persons under twenty one (21) years of age who are on the licensed premises for
the limited purpose of performing maintenance, construction, remodeling,
painting or other similar services relating to the building or equipment
installation, repair or maintenance on the premises during those hours when the
licensed establishment is closed for business. The provisions of this section
shall not prohibit persons under twenty one (21) years of age from being
admitted to an area which has as its main purpose some objective other than the
sale or mixing or serving of alcoholic beverages, in which sales or serving of
alcoholic beverages are incidental to the main purpose, as long as the persons
under twenty one (21) years of age are not sold or served alcoholic beverages.
The incidental service of food in the bar area shall not exempt a licensee from
the provisions of this section. The ABLE Commission shall have the authority to
designate the portions of the premises of a licensee where persons under twenty
one (21) years of age shall not be admitted pursuant to this section. When
determining a licensee's main purpose, a licensee that operates a full kitchen,
sells food items from a full menu, and has thirty five percent (35%) or more of
its monthly gross sales attributable to food items, shall have as its main
purpose other than the sale of alcoholic beverages. The main purpose of those
mixed beverage establishments whose main purpose was other than the sale of
alcoholic beverages prior to October 1, 2018, shall not automatically lose that
designation upon the elimination of low- point beer in the State. If the ABLE
Commission wishes to change said mixed beverage establishments' main purpose
designation, it shall be the burden of the ABLE Commission to prove by clear
and convincing evidence that said mixed beverage establishments no longer
qualify for that designation. (Ord. 424, 9-25-2018, eff. 10-1-2018)
3-3A-11: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
If any person having an Occupational Tax permit as provided for herein is
convicted more than once of a violation of the terms hereof, said permit may be
revoked by the Council. Furthermore, if any person having a license, as
provided for in the Alcoholic Beverage Control Act, is convicted more than once
of a violation of the terms hereof, said license may be revoked as provided in
the Alcoholic Beverage Control Act. (Ord. 424, 9-25-2018, eff. 10-1-2018)
ARTICLE B.  RETAIL STORES; OFF PREMISES CONSUMPTION
SECTION:
3-3B-1: Occupational Tax Levied
3-3B-2: Payment Required And Penalty
3-3B-3: Deliveries
3-3B-4: Duty Of Operators And Prohibited Conduct On Sales Premises
3-3B-5: Hours Of Operation
3-3B-6: Employment
3-3B-7: Revocation Of License
3-3B-8: Enforcement
3-3B-1: OCCUPATIONAL TAX LEVIED:
No person shall operate, manage, or work in any retail establishment that
sells, for off premises consumption only, any type of alcoholic beverage, as
that term is found in 37A Oklahoma Statutes section 1-103 without having
previously paid the Occupational Tax as provided in this chapter. (Ord. 424, 9-
25-2018, eff. 10-1-2018)
3-3B-2: PAYMENT REQUIRED AND PENALTY:
   A.   Any State licensee originally entering upon any occupation herein
listed shall pay the tax therefor at the Office of the City Clerk on or before
the date upon which he enters upon such occupation. Said licensee shall provide
a copy of a current State license before payment of an Occupation Tax will be
accepted. Thereafter, the licensee shall pay the tax annually on or before the
first day of April now and through October 31, 2019. Effective November 1,
2019, the licensee shall pay the tax annually on or before the first day of
November.
   B.   The Occupation Tax subject to this section shall be prorated on a
monthly basis for the year in which an occupation began operations.
   C.   Upon payment of the said Occupation Tax, the City Clerk shall issue a
receipt to said State licensee, which said licensee shall post in a conspicuous
place on the occupation premises to exhibit that said licensee is permitted by
the City to enter upon such occupation on said premises.
   D.   Any person who engages in any of the occupations taxed by this chapter
without paying said Occupation Tax imposed therefor in advance of such
operation, is guilty of an offense against the City, and upon conviction
thereof shall be fined the sum of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00),
excluding costs. Each day of such violation shall constitute a separate
offense. (Ord. 424, 9-25-2018, eff. 10-1-2018)
3-3B-3: DELIVERIES:
No wholesale dealer in alcoholic beverages shall sell or deliver to any retail
spirits store any alcoholic beverages on Sundays, New Year's Day, Fourth of
July, Thanksgiving, or Christmas Day. (Ord. 424, 9-25-2018, eff. 10-1-2018)
3-3B-4: DUTY OF OPERATORS AND PROHIBITED CONDUCT ON SALES PREMISES:
It is hereby declared unlawful for any person operating any retail
establishment that sells, for off premises consumption only, any type of
alcoholic beverage, to permit any person under the age of twenty one (21) years
to loiter in or be in such a place, or to permit any intoxicated person to loaf
or loiter or be in or about said place of business, or to permit any person to
violate any of the law of the State. (Ord. 424, 9-25-2018, eff. 10-1-2018)
3-3B-5: HOURS OF OPERATION:
   A.   Retail Spirit Stores: No retail spirits store may sell any alcoholic
beverages at any hour other than between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M.
and twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight Monday through Saturday. Further, no person
shall open or operate a retail spirits store on the following days:
      1.   Thanksgiving Day.
      2.   Christmas Day.
   B.   Retail Beer Or Retail Wine Stores: A retail wine or retail beer
establishment may offer wine or beer for sale on Monday through Sunday between
the hours of six o'clock (6:00) A.M. and two o'clock (2:00) A.M. the following
day.
   C.   Elections: Retail spirit, retail beer, and retail wine licensees shall
be permitted to sell alcoholic beverages on the day of any general, primary,
runoff primary or special election whether on a national, State, County or City
election, provided that the election day does not occur on any day on which
such sales are otherwise prohibited by law. (Ord. 424, 9-25-2018, eff. 10-1-
2018)
3-3B-6: EMPLOYMENT:
No person shall employ any person under eighteen (18) years of age in the
selling of beer or wine or employ any person under twenty one (21) years of age
in the selling of spirits. (Ord. 424, 9-25-2018, eff. 10-1-2018)
3-3B-7: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
If any person having an Occupational Tax permit as provided for herein is
convicted more than once of a violation of the terms hereof, said permit may be
revoked by the Council. Furthermore, if any person having a license, as
provided for in the Alcoholic Beverage Control Act, is convicted more than once
of a violation of the terms hereof, said license may be revoked as provided in
the Alcoholic Beverage Control Act. (Ord. 424, 9-25-2018, eff. 10-1-2018)
3-3B-8: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   The Marlow Police Department is authorized and empowered to enforce the
provisions of this chapter. The provisions shall be enforced in a manner that
can reasonably be expected to reduce the extent to which alcohol is sold or
distributed to persons under twenty one (21) years of age.
   B.   Persons under twenty one (21) years of age may be enlisted by the
Marlow Police Department to assist in enforcement. Provided, however, that such
persons may be used to test compliance only if the testing is conducted under
the direct supervision of the Marlow Police Department; provided, written
parental consent shall be obtained prior to the use of any person under the age
of eighteen (18) years. Any other use of persons under twenty one (21) years of
age to test compliance shall be unlawful and punishable by assessment of an
administrative fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 424, 9-25-2018,
eff. 10-1-2018)
CHAPTER 4
TOBACCO PRODUCTS SALES; YOUTH ADDICTION
SECTION:
3-4-1: Findings And Intent
3-4-2: Definitions
3-4-3: Distribution And Sales; Identification
3-4-4: Distribution Of Samples
3-4-5: Tobacco Sales In Original, Sealed Packaging
3-4-6: Possession By Minor; Falsifying Proof Of Age
3-4-7: Reporting To State
3-4-8: Nonretaliation
3-4-1: FINDINGS AND INTENT:
The mayor and city council find that youth addiction to tobacco products is a
public health problem with grave health consequences. In recognition that
almost ninety percent (90%) of all smokers begin smoking by the age of eighteen
(18), action is needed to curtail the easy access of minors to cigarettes and
other addictive tobacco products. Furthermore, the mayor and city council find
that the Oklahoma state legislature has limited the powers granted to local
governments to address the problems of youth access to tobacco. Therefore, the
intent of this chapter is to:
   A.   Implement the strictest and most enforceable system allowed under
Oklahoma state law to prevent the illegal sale of cigarettes and other tobacco
products to minors;
   B.   Periodically amend and update this chapter as necessary to best utilize
any applicable powers which may be returned to Oklahoma municipalities in the
future; and
   C.   Educate, encourage and assist underage tobacco users in ceasing all use
of addictive tobacco products, preferably before daily use of such products is
initiated. (Ord. 349, 4-28-1998)
3-4-2: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in the section:
   PERSON: Any individual, firm, fiduciary, partnership, corporation, trust, or
association, however formed.
   PROOF OF AGE: A driver's license, license for identification only, or other
generally accepted means of identification that describes the individual as
eighteen (18) years of age or older and contains a photograph or other likeness
of the individual and appears on its face to be valid.
   SAMPLE: A tobacco product distributed to members of the public at no cost
for the purpose of promoting the product.
   SAMPLING: The distribution of samples to members of the public.
   TOBACCO PRODUCT: Any product that contains tobacco and is intended for human
consumption. (Ord. 349, 4-28-1998)
3-4-3: DISTRIBUTION AND SALES; IDENTIFICATION:
   A.   Furnishing To Underage Person: It is unlawful for any person to sell or
furnish in any manner any tobacco product to another person who is under
eighteen (18) years of age, or to handle tobacco products on behalf of any such
person.
   B.   Underage Employees: It shall not be unlawful for an employee under
eighteen (18) years of age to handle tobacco products when required in the
performance of the employee's duties.
   C.   Demand Proof Of Age: A person engaged in the sale or distribution of
tobacco products shall demand proof of age from a prospective purchaser or
recipient if any ordinary person would conclude on the basis of appearance that
the prospective purchaser may be under eighteen (18) years of age.
   D.   Failure To Require Proof Of Age: If an individual engaged in the sale
or distribution of tobacco products has demanded proof of age from a
prospective purchaser or recipient who is not under eighteen (18) years of age,
the failure to subsequently require proof of age shall not constitute a
violation of this chapter.
   E.   Guilt Of Employee: If the sale is made by an employee of the owner of a
store at which tobacco products are sold at retail, the employee shall be
guilty of the violation and shall be subject to the fine.
   F.   Defense To Action; Demanding Proof: Proof that the defendant demanded,
was shown, and reasonably relied upon proof of age, shall be a defense to any
action brought pursuant to this chapter.
   G.   Multiple Locations: For purposes of determining the liability of a
person controlling franchises or business operations in multiple locations for
any violation of subsection A or B of this section, each individual franchise
or business location shall be deemed a separate entity.
   H.   Violation; Fine: Any person who shall violate subsection A or B of this
section shall be guilty of an offense and may be assessed a fine of not more
than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense within a one year
period and two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the second offense or subsequent
offenses within a one year period.
   I.   Failure To Pay Fine: Upon failure of any person to pay any fine
authorized by this section within ninety (90) days of the day of the assessment
of such fine, the court clerk or his designee shall notify the Oklahoma
department of public safety, as such department is authorized to suspend or not
issue a driver's license to the person until proof of payment has been
provided. (Ord. 349, 4-28-1998)
3-4-4: DISTRIBUTION OF SAMPLES:
   A.   Distributing Near Playground Or School: No person shall distribute
tobacco product samples in or on any public street, sidewalk, or park that is
within three hundred feet (300') of any playground, school, or other facility
when the facility is being used primarily by persons under eighteen (18) years
of age.
   B.   Violation; Fine: Any person who shall violate subsection A of this
section shall be guilty of an offense and may be assessed a fine of not more
than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense within a one year
period and two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the second offense or subsequent
offenses within a one year period.
   C.   Failure To Pay Fine: Upon failure of any person to pay any fine
authorized by this section within ninety (90) days of the day of the assessment
of such fine, the court clerk or his designee shall notify the Oklahoma
department of public safety, as such department is authorized to suspend or not
issue a driver's license to the person until proof of payment has been
provided. (Ord. 349, 4-28-1998)
3-4-5: TOBACCO SALES IN ORIGINAL, SEALED PACKAGING:
   A.   Prohibition: It is unlawful for any person to sell cigarettes except in
the original, sealed package in which they were placed by the manufacturer.
   B.   Violation; Fine: Any person who shall violate subsection A of this
section shall be guilty of an offense and may be assessed a fine of not more
than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. (Ord. 349, 4-28-1998)
3-4-6: POSSESSION BY MINOR; FALSIFYING PROOF OF AGE:
   A.   Prohibition: Except as provided under subsection
 3-4-3B of this chapter, it is unlawful for a person under eighteen (18) years
of age to purchase, receive, or have in their possession a tobacco product, or
to present or offer to any person any purported proof of age which is false or
fraudulent for the purpose of purchasing or receiving any tobacco product.
   B.   Tobacco Education Program Attendance: On conviction of an individual
for an offense under subsection A of this section, the court shall suspend
execution of sentence and shall require the defendant to attend a tobacco
education program. The court shall require the parent or guardian of the
defendant to attend the tobacco education program with the defendant.
   C.   Community Service In Lieu Of Education Program: If access to the
tobacco education program is not readily available, the court shall require the
defendant to perform eight (8) to twelve (12) hours of tobacco related
community service instead of attending a tobacco education program.
   D.   Remedial Action: The tobacco education program and the tobacco related
community services are remedial and are not punishment.
   E.   Evidence Of Completion Of Program Or Service: No later than the
ninetieth day after the date of conviction under subsection A of this section,
the defendant shall present to the court, in a manner required by the court,
evidence of satisfactory completion of the tobacco education program or the
tobacco related community service.
   F.   Court Action: On receipt of the evidence required under subsection E of
this section, the court shall:
      1.   If the defendant has been convicted of a previous offense under
subsection A of this section which offense occurred within one year prior to
the offense for which the defendant is currently charged, execute the sentence,
and at the discretion of the court, assess a fine of not less than ten dollars
($10.00) and not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00).
      2.   If the defendant has not been convicted of a previous offense under
subsection A of this section which offense occurred within one year prior to
the offense for which the defendant is currently charged, dismiss the complaint
and discharge the defendant.
   G.   Dismissal Of Complaint: If the court dismisses the complaint under
subsection F2 of this section, the defendant is released from all penalties and
disabilities resulting from the offense, except that the defendant is
considered to have been convicted of the offense if the defendant is
subsequently convicted of the same charge if such a repeat offense occurs
within one year of the dismissed offense.
   H.   Apply For Expungement: Any person convicted of an offense under
subsection A of this section may apply to the court to have the conviction
expunged. If the court finds that the individual satisfactorily completed the
tobacco education program or tobacco related community service ordered by the
court and that there has been no subsequent offense for a period of at least
one year after the date of the offense for which the person was convicted, the
court shall order the conviction and any complaint, verdict, sentence, or other
document relating to the offense to be expunged from the individual's record
and the conviction may not be shown or made known for any purpose.
   I.   Failure To Satisfy Penalty Or Fine; Driver's License Suspension: If the
defendant does not provide the evidence required under subsection E of this
section within the period specified by that subsection or upon failure of the
defendant to pay any fine authorized by this section within ninety (90) days of
the day of the assessment of such fine, the court clerk or his designee shall
notify the Oklahoma department of public safety, as such department is
authorized to suspend or not issue a driver's license to the person until the
required evidence or proof of payment has been provided. (Ord. 349, 4-28-1998)
3-4-7: REPORTING TO STATE:
The city clerk or his designee shall furnish any information or reports
required or requested by the Oklahoma alcoholic beverage law enforcement (ABLE)
commission in the form, manner and time as may be determined by the ABLE
commission. (Ord. 349, 4-28-1998)
3-4-8: NONRETALIATION:
No person shall discharge, refuse to hire or in any manner retaliate against
any employee, applicant for employment or customer because such employee,
applicant, or customer reported violations of any provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 349, 4-28-1998)
CHAPTER 5
POOL, BILLIARD AND OTHER RECREATIONAL HALLS
SECTION:
3-5-1: Underage Persons Restricted
3-5-2: Prohibited Acts
3-5-3: Family Recreation Centers
3-5-4: Penalty
3-5-1: UNDERAGE PERSONS RESTRICTED:
   A.   Employment: It shall be unlawful for any owner, manager or operator to
employ or permit any minor (as defined by current state law) to work in a pool,
billiard, domino or card hall or parlor; and it shall be unlawful for any minor
(as defined by current state law) to work in such a hall or parlor.
   B.   Loitering On Premises:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person in charge of any hall or parlor
mentioned in subsection A of this section to permit any minor (as defined by
current state law) to loiter in such a hall or parlor, or to play games
therein, unless he is accompanied by a parent or guardian.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for such person to loiter in such a hall or
parlor, or to play games therein, unless he is accompanied by a parent or
guardian. (1985 Code § 5-58)
3-5-2: PROHIBITED ACTS:
It shall be unlawful for the owner, manager or operator of a pool, snooker,
billiard, domino or card hall or parlor, or bowling alley to permit therein
gambling, betting, or operation of a lottery; the sale, furnishing or drinking
of intoxicating liquor; disorderly conduct; loud or disturbing language; noise;
loud music; profane language; or any other violation of state laws or this
code. (1985 Code § 5-58)
3-5-3: FAMILY RECREATION CENTERS:
   A.   Exception: Sections
3-5-1 and
3-5-2 of this chapter shall not, however, apply to establishments created as
family entertainment and recreation centers for the use and enjoyment of the
entire family (regardless of age).
   B.   Liquor Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for the owner, manager or
operator of such a family center to permit the sale, furnishing or drinking of
alcoholic beverages of any type. (1985 Code § 5-58)
3-5-4: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be subject to penalty as provided in section
3-1A-5 of this title. (2004 Code)
CHAPTER 6
PAWNBROKERS
SECTION:
3-6-1: Definition
3-6-2: Licenses Required; Fee
3-6-3: Register Of Transactions; Inspection
3-6-4: Hours Of Business
3-6-5: Restrictions On Operation
3-6-6: Suspicious Circumstances
3-6-7: Penalty; License Revocation
3-6-1: DEFINITION:
A "pawnbroker" shall be defined as any person who lends money upon deposit, or
pledge of personal property or valuable thing, or any person who lends money
upon chattel or personal property for security, and required possession of
property so mortgaged, on condition of returning the same upon payment of a
stipulated amount of money. (2004 Code)
3-6-2: LICENSES REQUIRED; FEE:
   A.   Licenses Required: No person, corporation, partnership or association
of any kind shall carry on the business of a pawnbroker without first having
obtained a license to do so from the state of Oklahoma and the city of Marlow.
The city shall issue a license upon documentation of a state license. (2004
Code)
   B.   Fee: Each and every person engaged in the business of being a
pawnbroker or person engaged in the business of making loans on pledges of
chattel or personal property shall, before the exercise of said occupation, pay
a license fee as prescribed by resolution of the city council. (1985 Code § 5-
59; amd. 2004 Code)
3-6-3: REGISTER OF TRANSACTIONS; INSPECTION:
   A.   Register Required:
      1.   Every pawnbroker shall keep at his place of business a register in
which he shall enter in writing a detailed description of all property taken,
purchased or received by him, including any number that may be in stock of such
article or articles, together with the time and the name and place of residence
(giving street and number, if within the city) of the person leaving said
property; also, the amount loaned, the interest charged and the time when the
loan falls due.
      2.   Said register shall be kept clean, in good order and plainly
legible.
      3.   Such entries shall be made within one hour after the receipt or
purchase of any and all such property.
   B.   Entries; Furnish To Police Chief:
      1.   Every entry shall be made in the register in ink and shall not in
any manner be obliterated or erased.
      2.   The pawnbroker shall give a plainly written or printed ticket to the
person negotiating or leaving such property, having upon it a full and perfect
copy of all the entries required by ordinance to be kept in such register, for
which copy no charge shall be made. (1985 Code § 5-60)
      3.   It shall be the further duty of each and every pawnbroker to make
said register available for inspection upon request of the police department.
(1985 Code § 5-60; amd. 2004 Code)
   C.   Goods Purchased From Wholesalers Excepted: No person shall be required
to furnish such description of any property purchased from manufacturers or
wholesale dealers having an established place of business, or of any goods
purchased at open sale or from any bankrupt stock or from any other person
having an established place of business. Such goods shall be accompanied by a
bill of sale or other written evidence of open and legitimate purchase, and
shall be exhibited to any public officer when demanded.
   D.   Inspection By City And County Officials:
      1.   Said register, so kept by said person, shall at all times be open to
the inspection of the city police, and the sheriff or deputy sheriffs of
Stephens County, or by any person authorized in writing for that purpose by any
of such officers, which authority shall be exhibited to said pawnbroker.
      2.   Said pawnbroker shall, upon request, show and exhibit to such person
or officer, for inspection, any article purchased, taken or received by him,
unless the time of the pledge has expired and the goods have been sold and
delivered to the purchaser. (1985 Code § 5-60)
3-6-4: HOURS OF BUSINESS:
No pawnbroker shall purchase, receive or take on deposit from any person, any
article of property between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and six
o'clock (6:00) A.M.; and such places of business shall remain closed all day
Sunday. (1985 Code § 5-61)
3-6-5: RESTRICTIONS ON OPERATION:
   A.   Persons Under The Influence Of Liquor Or Drugs: It shall be unlawful
and an offense in the city for any pawnbroker or the proprietor or his employee
in such cases, or for any person whosoever to purchase, take or receive in
pledge, by gift or on deposit, or to accept possession of any article or
property from, any common drunkard or person under the influence of alcoholic
beverages or drugs. (1985 Code § 5-62)
   B.   Minors: It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person in the city
in charge of any pawnshop to purchase from, or advance any money to, any minor
under the age of eighteen (18) years, upon any thing or article of value, or to
have any dealings with such minor with respect to the title of chattel or
personal property, without the written consent of the parent or guardian of
such minor, which said consent shall be kept on file and subject to police
inspection. (1985 Code § 5-63; amd. 2004 Code)
3-6-6: SUSPICIOUS CIRCUMSTANCES:
   A.   Suspicion Of Stolen Property: Any suspicious circumstances, sufficient
to put any ordinarily prudent person upon his guard, shall be sufficient notice
to any pawnbroker or person making loans on pledged chattel, or purchasing the
same, that the property involved or tendered is, or may be, stolen property.
   B.   Proof Of Right To Dispose Of Property: Any knowledge, notice or
information as to the improper character of the person offering chattel in
pledge shall, in each case, require positive proof of the holder's right to
dispose of said property.
   C.   Aiding Crime Of Petty Theft: Any person or pawnbroker making any loans
upon chattel from persons, where the circumstances of title are uncertain to
any extent as to the legal right of the holder to dispose of such property,
shall, by the act of making such loan, become an aider and abettor of the crime
of petty theft in any and all cases where it has been, or may be, established,
by any court of competent jurisdiction that the said chattel was illegally
acquired or illegally disposed of by said holder. (1985 Code § 5-64)
3-6-7: PENALTY; LICENSE REVOCATION:
   A.   Penalty: Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall,
upon conviction thereof, be subject to penalty as provided in section
3-1A-5 of this title. (2004 Code)
   B.   License Revocation: Upon conviction of any pawnbroker, or any other
person who may be engaged in any calling or occupation which shall, under the
present or future ordinances of the city, require a license or permit, who
shall be guilty of the violation of any of the provisions hereof, in addition
to the fine otherwise provided as a penalty therefor, the municipal judge shall
order such license or permit to be revoked 1 . (1985 Code § 5-65)
 
Notes
  1. See also sections
1 3-1-12 and
  3-1-13 of this title.
CHAPTER 7
CONTRACTORS
SECTION:
3-7-1: Plumbers; Registration And Fee
3-7-2: Electricians; Registration And Fees
3-7-3: Penalty
3-7-1: PLUMBERS; REGISTRATION AND FEE:
   A.   Registration Required: Any person desiring to engage in the business of
plumbing in the city shall first register with the city clerk, and provide
evidence of a bond in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00).
   B.   Gas Fitting By Registered Plumber: No person shall do any gas fitting,
extensions, connection of fixtures or repairs to any gas fitting, except a
registered plumber, as provided in this code.
   C.   Registration Fee: The fee for registration for a contractor's license
shall be as prescribed by resolution of the city council. (1985 Code § 4-39;
amd. 2004 Code)
3-7-2: ELECTRICIANS; REGISTRATION AND FEES:
   A.   Registration Required: All persons, firms, partnerships, corporations
or individuals, engaged locally, or hereafter engaging, in the business of
installing electrical fixtures, wiring or apparatus in or on any building
within the corporate limits of the city shall register with the city clerk
before they may engage in said business, and shall first provide evidence of a
bond in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00).
   B.   Fees:
      1.   The registration fee for an electrician contractor, a journeyman, or
a mechanical contractor license shall be as prescribed by resolution of the
city council. (1985 Code § 4-40; amd. 2004 Code)
      2.   Apprentices shall register but will not be required to pay any
registration fee. (Ord. 327, 8-30-1994)
3-7-3: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be subject to penalty as provided in section
3-1A-5 of this title. (2004 Code)
CHAPTER 8
ITINERANT OCCUPATIONS
SECTION:
3-8-1: Definition
3-8-2: Licensing And Bond Requirements; Fees
3-8-3: Lost License; Duplicate; Fee
3-8-4: Sales Restrictions; Exceptions
3-8-5: Payment Of State And Local Taxes
3-8-6: Hours Restricted
3-8-7: Revocation Of License
3-8-8: Penalty
3-8-1: DEFINITION:
"Itinerant occupations, trades, businesses or solicitations" shall mean those
occupations, trades, businesses and solicitations having no permanent
warehouse, building, structure, residence or place of business within the city
at which a permanent business is carried on throughout the year or usual
production season in good faith (and not for the purpose of evading the
provisions of this chapter), and shall include occupations, trades, businesses
and solicitations housed in temporary stands or quarters (including permanent
quarters occupied pursuant to any temporary arrangement), or carried on by
means of house to house solicitation or upon the streets and sidewalks of the
city; provided however, that no occupation, trade or business engaged in by a
charitable, educational or religious organization, association or club having a
membership duly enrolled in accordance with the rules, regulations, and bylaws
of said organization, association or club and the majority of said members
being residents of the city of Marlow or of Stephens County, Oklahoma, shall be
considered an "itinerant occupation, trade, business or solicitation". (1985
Code § 5-1)
3-8-2: LICENSING AND BOND REQUIREMENTS; FEES:
   A.   License Required: It shall be an offense for any person to engage in
any kind of itinerant occupation in the city without first having obtained an
itinerant occupation license from the office of the city clerk. (1985 Code § 5-
2)
   B.   License Fees: License fees shall be as established by resolution of the
city council for persons, firms, associations and corporations engaged in
itinerant occupations, trades, businesses or solicitations within the city.
(1985 Code § 5-2; amd. 2004 Code)
   C.   Separate License For Each Business: Every person, firm, association or
corporation who engages in an occupation or business for which an itinerant
occupation license is required shall pay the fee and secure a separate license
for each such business or occupation.
   D.   Display Of License: Every holder of a license to engage in, exercise or
pursue a business, profession, trade, occupation or privilege shall carry the
license and shall display it to any person who requests to see it.
   E.   License Nontransferable: Assignment or transfer of licenses shall not
be permitted. (1985 Code § 5-3)
   F.   Bond: A bond in the amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) shall
be required for any person licensed as provided for in this chapter. (2004
Code)
3-8-3: LOST LICENSE; DUPLICATE; FEE:
   A.   Issuance Of Duplicate: Whenever an itinerant occupation license has
been lost or destroyed without any wrongful act or connivance by the holder,
the city clerk, on application, may issue a duplicate license for the unexpired
time.
   B.   Affidavit: Before the duplicate is issued, the holder shall file with
the city clerk an affidavit that the license has not been transferred, that it
has been lost or destroyed without any wrongful act or connivance by the
holder, and that, if believed lost, he has made a diligent search for it and
has not been able to find it.
   C.   Fee: The fee for every duplicate license issued, payable to the city
clerk, shall be one dollar ($1.00). (1985 Code § 5-3)
3-8-4: SALES RESTRICTIONS; EXCEPTIONS:
Each person, firm or corporation engaged in occupations, trades or businesses
defined as "itinerant occupations" in section
3-8-1 of this chapter shall be prohibited from door to door solicitation in all
areas within the central business district of the city; provided, that this
shall not apply to persons selling farm products produced within this state, by
themselves, nor shall this prohibit solicitation for activities excluded under
the definition of "itinerant occupation" in section
3-8-1 of this chapter. (1985 Code § 5-3)
3-8-5: PAYMENT OF STATE AND LOCAL TAXES:
Each applicant for an itinerant occupation license shall provide written proof
or certification to the city clerk that the applicant will collect and remit
state and local sales taxes to the city, if required by state law and municipal
ordinance. (1985 Code § 5-3)
3-8-6: HOURS RESTRICTED:
No person, firm, association or corporation to whom an itinerant occupation
license has been issued shall conduct, exercise or pursue the business or
occupation for which such license is issued any day between the hours of five
o'clock (5:00) P.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. (on the following day). (1985
Code § 5-3)
3-8-7: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
An itinerant occupation license issued to any person, firm, association or
corporation may be revoked by the city council, after adequate opportunity for
a hearing, for any one of the following reasons:
   A.   That the licensee is engaging in, exercising or pursuing the business
or occupation in such a manner that he has created or is creating a public
nuisance; or
   B.   Serious or repeated violation of the law or ordinances. (1985 Code § 5-
3)
3-8-8: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be subject to penalty as provided in section
3-1A-5 of this title. (2004 Code)
CHAPTER 9
PRIVATE AMBULANCE SERVICES
SECTION:
3-9-1: Definitions
3-9-2: Emergency Medical Services Board
3-9-3: Certificate Of Public Convenience And Necessity
3-9-4: General And Vehicle Insurance Required
3-9-5: Bond Required
3-9-6: Vehicle Permits
3-9-7: Registration Of Ambulance Drivers And Attendants
3-9-8: Appeal
3-9-9: Fees For Ambulance Service
3-9-10: Discontinuance Of Service; Notify City
3-9-11: City Register Of Operators And Vehicles
3-9-12: Right To Inspect Records And Equipment
3-9-13: Operators Report To City; Transporting Patients
3-9-14: Emergency Medical Services Made Available
3-9-15: Dead On Arrival Procedure
3-9-16: Penalty
3-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words, and their
derivations, shall have the meanings given herein. The word "shall" is always
mandatory and not merely directory. The word "city" as used herein means all
areas within the territorial limits of the city.
   AMBULANCE: Any motor vehicle equipped with facilities therein to convey
infirm or injured persons.
   ATTENDANT: Any person who has the duty of caring for a sick, ill or injured
person in an ambulance, and who is registered with the city of Marlow,
Oklahoma, and certified by the state of Oklahoma as an emergency medical
technician (EMT).
   BOARD: The Marlow emergency medical services board, as herein established.
   CERTIFICATE: A certificate of public convenience and necessity issued by the
city council of the city of Marlow, Oklahoma, licensing an operator as
hereinafter defined.
   CLERK: The city clerk of the city of Marlow, Oklahoma, or her designated
representative.
   COUNCIL: The city council of the city of Marlow, Oklahoma.
   DRIVER: Every individual who shall drive an "ambulance", as herein defined,
who has a commercial chauffeur's license issued by the state department of
public safety, and who is registered with the city of Marlow, Oklahoma.
   OPERATOR: Any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business as the
owner or proprietor of ambulances.
   PERMIT: The operating permit which an operator is required to obtain
annually for each and every motor vehicle operated as an ambulance.
   PERSON: Any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation, or
other group or combination acting as a unit.
   REGISTRATION: The registration of drivers and attendants by the city of
Marlow, Oklahoma. (1985 Code § 5-20; amd. 2004 Code)
3-9-2: EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES BOARD:
   A.   Board Created; Membership; Terms:
      1.   Board Created; Responsibilities: There is hereby created an
emergency medical services board to act in an advisory capacity to the city
council in the development, formulation and alteration of rules, regulations
and standards for the operation of ambulances, certification of operators,
issuance of permits, and registrations as defined herein. The board shall be
responsible for continuing study and recommendations concerning the emergency
medical services of the city.
      2.   Membership: The board shall consist of seven (7) members, as
follows:
         a.   A member who is a licensed physician and who is also a member of
the Stephens County medical society;
         b.   A member who is a representative of one of the local hospital
administrations;
         c.   A member who is a representative from the state nurses
association;
         d.   A member who is a representative of one of the local law
enforcement agencies; and
         e.   Three (3) members from the community at large. (Ord. 336, 6-27-
1995)
      3.   Compensation: All board members shall serve without compensation.
      4.   Appointment; Terms:
         a.   The members shall be appointed by the mayor, with the approval of
the city council, for a term of three (3) years, except that initially two (2)
of the members shall be appointed for three (3) year terms, three (3) of the
members shall be appointed for two (2) year terms, and two (2) of the members
shall be appointed for a one year term.
         b.   All members shall hold office until their successors are
appointed.
         c.   The initial members of the board shall be appointed within two
(2) weeks of the date of the initial enactment of this chapter. (Ord. 336, 6-
27-1995; amd. 2004 Code)
   B.   Organization Of Board; Meetings:
      1.   Chairman: The board shall select annually a chairman from among its
members.
      2.   Meetings:
         a.   The board shall hold at least three (3) regular meetings each
year and such additional meetings as the chairman deems necessary.
         b.   Special meetings may be called by the chairman, or upon written
request of any four (4) members.
      3.   Quorum: Four (4) members of the board shall constitute a quorum.
(1985 Code § 5-30)
      4.   Minutes Maintained: The city clerk or his designee shall maintain
minutes of each board meeting and provide a copy of same to the city council.
(1985 Code § 5-30; amd. 2004 Code)
   C.   Duties:
      1.   Rules And Standards Submitted To Council: Within thirty (30) days
from the time of its appointment, the board shall submit to the city council
its initial rules, regulations and standards for operation of ambulances,
certification of operators, issuance of permits and registrations as defined
herein.
      2.   Approval By Council Resolution: The rules, regulations and standards
formulated by the board and approved by the council shall become effective when
adopted by the city council by resolution.
      3.   Compliance With National And State Standards: At no time shall the
standards for ambulance service operation, ambulance service personnel, or
ambulance service equipment, as adopted hereunder, be less than the current
minimal standards adopted by the committee on trauma of the American college of
surgeons, national highway safety bureau, and the Oklahoma state department of
health. (1985 Code § 5-31)
3-9-3: CERTIFICATE OF PUBLIC CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY:
   A.   Certificate Required; Exceptions:
      1.   Requirement; Exceptions: Commencing with the passage and publication
of this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be
operated an ambulance within the city without first having obtained a
certificate of public convenience and necessity from the city council.
Provided, however, that no such certificate shall be required for any person
operating an ambulance or other vehicle who:
         a.   Renders assistance during any catastrophe or major emergency when
the ambulances authorized to operate in the city by certificate are
insufficient in number or for any other reason inadequate;
         b.   Operates from a location outside the city and transports any
patient from a point of origin outside the city to a destination inside the
city;
         c.   Operates from a location outside the city and transports any
patient from a point of origin within the city to a destination outside the
city;
         d.   Operates as a municipal service agency, including police and fire
rescue units; or
         e.   Private companies operating an ambulance solely for the
transportation of their employees for illness or injuries sustained while
performing their work.
      2.   Compliance With Rules And Standards: Any person having been issued
said certificate shall comply with all provisions of this chapter, and the
standards, rules and regulations adopted hereunder, as well as all other
applicable local, state and federal laws.
      3.   Existing Operators: Operators in business in the city on the date of
initial enactment of this chapter shall, upon application to the city council,
be issued a certificate covering the number of ambulances presently being
operated. These operators shall be granted ninety (90) days to comply with any
and all rules, regulations and standards adopted under this chapter.
   B.   Application For Certificate:
      1.   Filing Application: Applications for said certificate shall be filed
with the city clerk on forms provided by that officer.
      2.   Contents Of Application: Each application shall be signed and sworn
to by the applicant and shall contain at least the following:
         a.   The name and address of the applicant;
         b.   The trade name under which the applicant does or proposes to do
business;
         c.   If the applicant is an individual, the name, age and address of
the applicant, and the length of time the applicant has resided in the city;
         d.   If the applicant is a partnership or association, the business
name thereof, and the name, age and address of each partner, and the length of
time each partner has resided in the city;
         e.   If the applicant is a corporation, the names and addresses of all
officers and directors of such corporation;
         f.   The number of ambulances for which the certificate is requested;
         g.   The locations at which the ambulances are to be stationed;
         h.   Whether or not the applicant has been finally convicted of any
felony or other offenses involving moral turpitude;
         i.   Whether or not the applicant has any claims or judgments against
him for damages resulting from the negligent operation of an ambulance;
         j.   The financial ability and responsibility of the applicant; and
         k.   Such other information as the city clerk may require in order to
evaluate the applicant. (1985 Code § 5-22)
   C.   Investigation Of Applicant; Issuance Of Certificate; Fee:
      1.   Upon receipt of an application for a certificate, the city clerk
shall cause an investigation to be made of the applicant and the proposed
application shall be referred to the board for evaluation and recommendation.
(1985 Code § 5-24)
      2.   The recommendations of the board shall then be submitted to the city
council for review. If the city council approves the application, a certificate
shall be issued by the city clerk, upon payment of a fee as established by
resolution of the city council. A copy of every certificate shall be filed with
the city clerk.
   D.   Term; Annual Fee; Revocation; Nontransferable:
      1.   A certificate of public convenience and necessity shall be issued
for a period of three (3) years, subject, however, to an annual renewal fee as
established by resolution of the city council and an annual review of the
Marlow emergency medical services board and city council. (1985 Code § 5-24;
amd. 2004 Code)
      2.   Said certificate may be suspended or revoked by the city council
only for a good cause. It may, however, be altered or amended by said council
on recommendation of the board.
      3.   A certificate shall not be transferable to any other person without
the approval of the city council. (1985 Code § 5-24)
   E.   Form And Contents Of Certificate: Every certificate issued shall be
signed by the mayor, attested by the city clerk and shall contain the name and
address of the applicant, and the number of vehicles authorized to be operated
pursuant to such certificate. (1985 Code § 5-28)
3-9-4: GENERAL AND VEHICLE INSURANCE REQUIRED:
   A.   Insurance Required: Every operator shall carry general and auto
liability and property damage insurance with solvent and responsible insurers
authorized to transact business in the state of Oklahoma, to secure payment for
any loss or damage resulting from any occurrence arising out of, or caused by,
the operation or use of any of the operator's motor vehicles.
   B.   Amount Of Vehicle Insurance: Each vehicle shall be insured for the sum
of at least one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for injuries to, or
death of, any one person arising out of any one accident and the sum of at
least three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for injuries to, or death of
more than one person in any one accident, and for the sum of at least fifty
thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for damages to property arising from any one
accident. Every insurance policy or contract for such insurance shall provide
for the operator and person insured, or any person driving in the insured
vehicle. Such insurance shall be obtained and certificates of insurance shall
be filed with the city clerk before a permit shall be issued.
   C.   Cancellation Notice: All such certificates of insurance shall provide
for a thirty (30) day cancellation notice to the licensing officer. (1985 Code
§ 5-25)
3-9-5: BOND REQUIRED:
Each operator shall furnish the city a performance bond in the amount of twenty
thousand dollars ($20,000.00) with sureties thereon agreeable to the city,
conditioned upon the operator complying with all the terms, conditions and
covenants of this chapter. (1985 Code § 5-26)
3-9-6: VEHICLE PERMITS:
   A.   Permit Required; Fee; Inspection:
      1.   After an operator has secured a certificate hereunder, no vehicle
shall be operated under authority of such certificate until that operator has
made application to the city clerk on forms provided by that office, for a
permit for each motor vehicle desired to be operated under said certificate.
(1985 Code § 5-32)
      2.   Every application for a permit shall be in writing, verified by the
operator holding the certificate, and shall contain the name and address of the
operator, the number of the certificate and the make, type, year of
manufacture, motor number, serial number and state license number of each
vehicle. The application shall be accompanied by a fee as prescribed by
resolution of the city council for each permit. (1985 Code § 5-32; amd. 2004
Code)
      3.   The clerk shall cause an inspection of each vehicle to be made to
determine if it can conform to the standards, requirements and regulations as
adopted under this chapter.
      4.   The clerk shall issue permits to those ambulances found to be in
compliance; provided, that the number of permits issued to any operator shall
not exceed the number designated in his certificate or amended certificate.
(1985 Code § 5-32)
   B.   Term; Nontransferable; Revocation:
      1.   All permits issued hereunder shall expire on December 31 of the year
in which they are issued and must be renewed by January 31 of the following
year.
      2.   No permit issued hereunder shall be assignable or transferable by
the person to whom issued, unless said assignment or transfer be approved by
the city council.
      3.   Permits may be suspended or revoked for noncompliance with the
rules, regulations and standards adopted under this chapter. (1985 Code § 5-33)
3-9-7: REGISTRATION OF AMBULANCE DRIVERS AND ATTENDANTS:
   A.   Registration Required; Standards And Training:
      1.   No person shall be employed or act as a driver or attendant unless
such person shall have been registered as a driver, or attendant by the city.
      2.   Registration shall be dependent upon the driver or attendant meeting
the standards, requirements and regulations adopted hereunder.
      3.   Such standards must include minimal physical qualifications,
personal background and training requirements.
      4.   Minimum training requirements for drivers and attendants shall
include a basic background in anatomy and physiology, vital signs and their
significance, the handling of life threatening emergencies, management of
injuries, burns and environmental emergencies, as well as acute poisoning,
emergency childbirth, management of the emotionally disturbed and unruly, and
other medical emergencies.
      5.   Minimum training requirements for the drivers shall assure a
knowledge and ability of ambulance operation, ability to follow assigned
routes, maintenance of vehicle, and use of communications equipment. (1985 Code
§ 5-34)
   B.   Application For Registration; Fee; Investigation:
      1.   Application for registration as a driver or attendant shall be made
in writing to the city clerk on forms provided by that office. Each application
shall be accompanied by a fee as prescribed by resolution of the city council.
The application shall contain the full name and street address of the applicant
and such other information as may be required by the city clerk to properly
identify the applicant and disclose any information as to his character,
reputation or physical qualifications of the applicant for registration as a
driver or attendant. (1985 Code § 5-35; amd. 2004 Code)
      2.   The city clerk shall be responsible for investigation of the
qualifications of the applicant and shall provide a copy of each application to
the Marlow police department. The department will investigate the police and
traffic record of the applicant and report to the city clerk. The city clerk
shall issue a registration card to those applicants found to qualify. (1985
Code § 5-35)
   C.   Accessibility Of Registration Cards: The registration card of each
driver and attendant shall be carried on the person of such driver or
attendant, or shall be immediately available in the central office of the
operator at all times while the driver or attendant is on duty. The
registration card shall be shown, upon request, to the city clerk, police or
other legal authority. (1985 Code § 5-36)
   D.   Term; Nontransferable; Revocation: All registrations issued hereunder
shall expire on June 30 next following their date of issuance and must be
renewed by the thirty first day of the following month. Registrations are
nonassignable and nontransferable, and may be revoked or suspended in
accordance with the standards, rules and regulations as adopted hereunder.
(1985 Code § 5-37)
3-9-8: APPEAL:
   A.   Right To Appeal; Time Limit: Any applicant and/or protestant shall have
the right to appeal any order relating to the issuance, denial, revocation,
alteration or suspension of the certificate, permit and/or registration to the
city council, by filing with the city clerk, within ten (10) days from the date
of said order, a written notice of appeal; said notice shall set forth the
grounds for the appeal.
   B.   Council Action: The city council may, after a hearing, sustain, reverse
or modify the order; provided however, that during the appeal taken from a city
council order upholding the denial, revocation, alteration or suspension of the
certificate, permit and/or registration, a protestant shall cease that activity
or conduct which was the subject matter of the hearing, pending a final
determination by an appellate tribunal. (1985 Code § 5-45)
3-9-9: FEES FOR AMBULANCE SERVICE:
   A.   Submit Schedule To Clerk: At the time an application is made for a
certificate, the operator shall submit to the clerk the schedule of fees which
he proposes to charge for ambulance service rendered under this chapter.
   B.   Review By Board: The fee schedule will be reviewed by the Marlow
emergency medical services board, and its recommendations concerning the
fairness and adequacy of the schedule will be made to the city council.
   C.   Council Approval: The fee schedule and any changes made therein must be
approved by the city council before it becomes effective. (1985 Code § 5-42)
3-9-10: DISCONTINUATION OF SERVICE; NOTIFY CITY:
   A.   Notify City; Time Limit: An operator shall give at least forty five
(45) days' notice to the city council prior to discontinuing operations or
prior to the expiration of the certificate, if he does not intend to apply for
renewal of the certificate.
   B.   Certified Mail: Said notice shall be given by certified mail to the
city clerk. (1985 Code § 5-27)
3-9-11: CITY REGISTER OF OPERATORS AND VEHICLES:
   A.   Operators; Description Of Vehicles: The city clerk shall keep a
register containing the names and addresses of all operators, the description
of their vehicles with their license numbers and a complete record of all
inspections of vehicles and equipment.
   B.   Drivers And Attendants: He shall also maintain a complete register of
all drivers and attendants, together with their registration numbers and a
complete record of all suspensions and revocations of certificates, permits and
registrations.
   C.   Fees Transmitted To Clerk: All fees for certificates, permits and
registrations, collected under this chapter shall be transmitted to the city
clerk. (1985 Code § 5-39)
3-9-12: RIGHT TO INSPECT RECORDS AND EQUIPMENT:
The city council or its duly authorized agent shall have the right to inspect
all records, vehicles, and equipment utilized by the operator certified under
this chapter. (1985 Code § 5-43)
3-9-13: OPERATORS REPORT TO CITY; TRANSPORTING PATIENTS:
An operator shall, within one week after transporting any patient within the
city, or from one place within the city to another place within or beyond its
limits, file a written report of the same with the city clerk, upon such form
as approved by the city council. (1985 Code § 5-39)
3-9-14: EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES MADE AVAILABLE:
The operator is strictly prohibited from withholding emergency medical services
to any patient because of inability to pay. Further, the operator shall
dispatch appropriate persons and equipment for each call received for emergency
medical service. (1985 Code § 5-44; amd. 2004 Code)
3-9-15: DEAD ON ARRIVAL PROCEDURE:
The following procedure shall be followed by all operators, drivers and
attendants when the subject of the emergency call is dead on arrival:
   A.   "Dead on arrival", as used herein, shall mean a determination of death
by a medical examiner, medical doctor, or doctor of osteopathy at the site of
the accident or upon arrival of the ambulance at its destination. The police
department must also be notified, and a police officer must be present at the
scene.
   B.   Operators and/or employees of operators providing an ambulance service
under the provisions of this chapter shall have no discretion over where such
body shall be delivered, except in accordance with the terms of this chapter
and they shall not recommend or suggest in any manner, direct or indirect, as
to where the body shall be delivered. (1985 Code § 5-40)
3-9-16: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be subject to penalty as provided in section
3-1A-5 of this title. (2004 Code)
CHAPTER 10
TAXICABS
SECTION:
3-10-1: Definition
3-10-2: Operator's License
3-10-3: Taxicab Driver's License
3-10-4: Insurance Required
3-10-5: Reasonable Rate For Services
3-10-6: Inspection Of Vehicles
3-10-7: Loud Noises Prohibited
3-10-8: Revocation Of License
3-10-9: Penalty
3-10-1: DEFINITION:
The term "vehicle for hire" as used in this chapter shall be construed to mean
any and all motor vehicles used by any person, firm, or corporation within the
city for the purpose of conducting a general taxicab business for the purpose
of realizing a profit from the operation of the vehicles. (Ord. 289, 9-30-1986)
3-10-2: OPERATOR'S LICENSE:
   A.   License Required; Fee Generally: Any person, firm or corporation owning
or operating a vehicle for hire or a taxicab company in the city shall secure
an operator's license in the amount as set by the city council per annum. The
license fee shall include the operation of one car, and for each additional car
a separate annual license fee is levied. The fees shall be paid to the city
clerk.
   B.   Application For License: Application for such license shall be made in
writing to the city clerk showing the name of the applicant, and the number and
make of each vehicle, and the motor number of each vehicle. The license number
assigned to each vehicle by the city clerk shall be contained in the
application.
   C.   License Term; Annual Fee:
      1.   All licenses shall be for a period of one year ending September 30,
following, and no reduction in the established license rates shall be allowed
for fractional parts of a year.
      2.   All licenses shall be on condition that the same may be revoked at
any time by the city council. (Ord. 289, 9-30-1986)
      3.   An occupational license fee as prescribed by resolution of the city
council shall also be paid per annum. (Ord. 289, 9-30-1986; amd. 2004 Code)
   D.   Transfer Of Vehicle License: In the event any such vehicle for hire is
discontinued as such after a license is issued for such vehicle, such license
may be transferred to another vehicle owned or operated by the person to whom
the same is issued, provided an insurance policy is secured as provided in this
chapter, upon application to the city clerk. (Ord. 289, 9-30-1986)
3-10-3: TAXICAB DRIVER'S LICENSE:
   A.   Municipal Driver's License; Fee: Every person who is in the service of
another or who shall operate any vehicle for hire shall first obtain a
municipal taxicab driver's license therefor. For such license, such driver
shall pay a fee as prescribed by resolution of the city council per annum.
(Ord. 289, 9-30-1986; amd. 2004 Code)
   B.   Application For License; Qualifications: No driver's license shall be
issued until the applicant shall make an application, setting out such matters
as may be prescribed by the city council, showing his/her qualifications as
such driver.
   C.   License Issuance; Conditions: Such application shall be made in writing
to the city clerk. The city clerk shall issue such license after he shall find
that such person is physically and mentally qualified as such driver, has
complied with the requirements in the application; but no person under the age
of twenty one (21) years shall be issued a driver's license.
   D.   Revocation Of Driver's License; Reasons: Such driver's license may be
revoked in the manner as provided herein for revoking the license of an owner
or operator of a vehicle for hire, at any time the city council shall find that
such person has made misrepresentations in his application for a license, or
that he has been found driving an automobile while under the influence of
intoxicating liquor or controlled or illegal drugs, or shall find that such
driver for any reason is an improper person to drive a vehicle for hire. (Ord.
289, 9-30-1986)
3-10-4: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
   A.   Requirement: Before any license shall be issued to and for any vehicle
for hire, the owner or operator thereof shall have first filed with the city
clerk a public liability insurance policy or a certified copy thereof to be
approved by the city clerk before issuing such license.
   B.   Liability Amounts: The liability under such insurance policy shall be
to the beneficiaries thereunder severally and jointly. Such policies shall
carry a personal injury liability to any person who may be insured, in the
amount of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or more; and shall carry a
liability of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) or more for the injuries and
damages resulting from a single accident to persons injured in such accident
and shall also provide for liability for property damage in the sum of ten
thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or more which may result from any single
accident.
   C.   Company Requirements: No policy shall be accepted by the city clerk
unless the same is issued by a licensed insurance company doing business in the
state. (Ord. 289, 9-30-1986)
3-10-5: REASONABLE RATE FOR SERVICES:
   A.   Rate Charged: The owner or operator of any vehicle for hire shall not
charge an unreasonable rate for their services, and shall only charge such rate
as may be from time to time prescribed by the city council. The charges shall
be subject to applicable state and city sales tax regulations.
   B.   Discrimination: Any owner or driver or operator of any vehicle for hire
shall forfeit his license at any time he shall make any discrimination of rates
or charges or services to or against any person. (Ord. 289, 9-30-1986)
3-10-6: INSPECTION OF VEHICLES:
   A.   Inspection By Police Officers: Vehicles for hire shall at all times be
subject to the inspections of the police officers of the city.
   B.   Defective Or Unsafe Condition: If the vehicles shall be found to be
defective or unsafe in any way for public use, the same shall not be operated
or used by such owner or operator as a vehicle for hire. (Ord. 289, 9-30-1986)
3-10-7: LOUD NOISES PROHIBITED:
No person shall, at any station or place, solicit any transportation business
by any loud noise or voice, instrument or other means. (Ord. 289, 9-30-1986)
3-10-8: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Any such license so issued, as provided in this chapter, shall be subject to
revocation by the city council at any time the council shall find that the
vehicle has been or is being operated in a careless and dangerous manner, or in
violation of the ordinances of the city or the laws of the state, or that the
owner or operator thereof is an improper person to operate the same. The owner
or operator of such vehicle shall have reasonable notice of the purported
revocation of such license, and may appear before the city council at a hearing
upon proposed revocation of such license. (Ord. 289, 9-30-1986)
3-10-9: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be subject to penalty as provided in section
3-1A-5 of this title. (2004 Code)
