from time to time, shall determine the price of lots in the cemetery and also
charges to be made for services at the cemetery. (1985 Code § 16-140)
   C.   Cemetery Care Fund: The cemetery care fund shall be established,
maintained, and used as provided in Oklahoma Statutes. (Ord. 325, 6-29-1993)
   D.   Cemetery Department: See section
1-10-3 of this code. (1985 Code § 16-142)
7-3-2: PURCHASE OR TRANSFER OF LOTS:
   A.   Sales Subject To Rules And Regulations: All lots shall be sold subject
to these rules and regulations or those hereafter adopted, and the deed of
title shall be stated. No lot shall be used for any purpose other than the
burial of human remains and the placing of appropriate monuments and memorials.
When an interment is to be made, a permit must be obtained from the city clerk
and signed by one of the heirs. Burial lots are exempt from ordinary taxes and
cannot be seized on execution. The city may impose specific charges against
lots. No mortgage or other encumbrance shall be given on any lot. An interment,
once properly made, shall not be disturbed, except on written consent of the
original owners or their heirs, and then only with the permission of the city
council or other duly appointed cemetery personnel.
   B.   Deed Of Title; Exception: When a lot is paid for in full, a deed of
title, for cemetery purposes only, shall be issued to the purchaser by the city
clerk. This subsection does not apply to indigent interment cases.
   C.   Recording Transfer Of Lots: The transfer of lots or parts of lots to
another person shall be reported to the city clerk for recording. No person
shall be recognized as owner or part owner unless so recorded. All transfers of
parts of lots less than that conveyed from the city to the lot owners must be
approved by the city clerk. (1985 Code § 16-141)
7-3-3: INTERMENTS AND DISINTERMENTS:
   A.   Interments; Burial Permits:
      1.   No interment shall take place without a burial permit, and not until
all laws, ordinances, rules and regulations relative to burials have been
complied with. No grave shall be opened unless the grave space has been paid
for, with the exception of indigent cases, or when the funeral director assumes
the responsibility of payment for such grave space or spaces. Funeral directors
making arrangements for burials shall be responsible for all interment charges
if not paid by the owner or agent. If the deceased to be interred is not a
member of the immediate family of the lot owner, permission in writing from
such owner must be filed with the city council or other duly appointed cemetery
personnel. This permission must be filed before the interment is made. (1985
Code § 16-141)
      2.   Only one interment in any one grave shall be permitted, except two
(2) infants may be permitted to be buried in one grave when approval is given
by the cemetery sexton. The city council or other duly appointed cemetery
personnel shall not be held responsible for errors in location of graves on
lots arising from improper instructions of lot owners. Orders from funeral
directors shall be construed as orders from owners. Under no circumstances
shall the city assume responsibility for error in opening graves when orders
are given by telephone.
   B.   Disinterments; Permission Required: Disinterment and removal of a body
shall not be made without the permission of the city administrator or other
duly appointed cemetery personnel, the lot owner, or the next of kin of the
deceased. Graves shall not be opened for inspection except for official
investigations. (1985 Code § 16-141; amd. 2004 Code)
7-3-4: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
   A.   Prohibited Acts: No person shall:
      1.   Enter the cemetery except through established gates;
      2.   Throw rubbish or debris on walks, drives or any cemetery grounds;
      3.   Pick or mutilate any flowers, either wild or domestic, or disturb
any trees, shrubs or other plants;
      4.   Consume refreshments or liquors within a cemetery or carry the same
onto the premises;
      5.   Permit any dog to enter or remain in the cemetery; or
      6.   Discharge any firearms or air rifles in or adjacent to the cemetery.
(This regulation shall not apply to authorized volleys at burials.)
   B.   Children In Cemetery: No children shall enter the cemetery unless
attended by adults responsible for the childrens' conduct.
   C.   Nonliability Of City: The city shall not be responsible for any damage
to lots, structures or objects thereon, or for flowers or articles removed from
any lot or grave.
   D.   Traffic And Animal Regulations: All traffic laws of the city that are
applicable to the operation of vehicles in cemeteries shall be strictly
observed. Persons driving in the cemetery shall be responsible for any damage
done by the vehicle or animal, or both, in the driver's charge. In addition, no
person shall:
      1.   Drive a vehicle in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour on any
cemetery road; (1985 Code § 16-141)
      2.   Drive off the established roads, unless permission is given in
writing by the cemetery sexton; (1985 Code § 16-141; amd. 2004 Code)
      3.   Make a U-turn on cemetery roads; or
      4.   Use any cemetery road as a public thoroughfare.
   E.   Lot Improvements, Council Approval: All plantings and other
improvements to lots shall be done with the approval of the city council or
other duly appointed cemetery personnel. (1985 Code § 16-141)
7-3-5: PENALTY:
Every person who violates any provision of this chapter, or maintains or
permits to continue any situation defined by this chapter as unlawful, shall be
guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to penalty
as provided in section 1-5-1 of this code. Every day upon which a violation
continues shall be deemed a separate offense. (1985 Code § 16-175; amd. 2004
Code)
CHAPTER 4
RAILROADS
SECTION:
7-4-1: Railroads To Improve Certain Streets And Alleys
7-4-2: Climbing On Trains
7-4-3: Loitering On Railroad Premises
7-4-4: Blocking Of Streets By Trains
7-4-5: Penalty
7-4-1: RAILROADS TO IMPROVE CERTAIN STREETS AND ALLEYS:
   A.   Streets: When a railway occupies or crosses any portion of a street
with its tracks either on or adjacent thereto, the railroad company shall
improve as much of the street as is occupied by its tracks and two feet (2') on
either side thereof, in a manner satisfactory to the city council.
   B.   Alleys: Whenever a railroad company crosses or occupies an alley with
its tracks, such company shall improve, drain, grade and/or pave such alley, in
order to eliminate problems created by the presence of its tracks.
   C.   Multiple Tracks Crossing Street: When more than one track crosses a
street within a distance of one hundred feet (100') (measuring from inside rail
to inside rail), the railroad company shall grade, drain and curb the street
area between its tracks and surface, in a manner satisfactory to the city
council.
   D.   Repair And Maintenance: Railroad companies shall keep all such
improvements made by them in good state of repair at all times. (1985 Code §
19-1)
7-4-2: CLIMBING ON TRAINS:
   A.   Attaching To Train While In Motion: It shall be unlawful for any person
to climb upon, hold to, or in any manner attach himself to, any train or
railroad car, while such is in motion within the city, unless such person is
acting in the line of duty.
   B.   Ticket Required: It shall also be unlawful to board any train or
railroad car (passenger, freight or other) without a proper ticket or the
permission of the person in charge of the train or railroad car, or not in the
line of duty. (1985 Code § 19-2)
7-4-3: LOITERING ON RAILROAD PREMISES:
It shall be unlawful for any person not acting within the line of duty, not
having any proper business or not being on any proper mission requiring his
presence there, to loiter anywhere at a railroad yard or upon other railroad
premises. (1985 Code § 19-4)
7-4-4: BLOCKING OF STREETS BY TRAINS:
It shall be unlawful for the operator of any train to block any street
intersection within the corporate boundaries of the city at any time for more
than five (5) minutes; provided, that this shall not apply to cars in motion,
other than those engaged in switching. (1985 Code § 19-5)
7-4-5: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who violates any provision of this chapter
shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to
penalty as provided in section
1-5-1 of this code. Each day's continuation of any such violation shall be
deemed a separate offense. (1985 Code § 19-20; amd. 2004 Code)
TITLE 8
UTILITIES
Municipal Utility Systems   1
Water System   2
Sewer System   3
Electric System   4
Solid Waste Collection And Disposal System   5
CHAPTER 1
MUNICIPAL UTILITY SYSTEMS
SECTION:
8-1-1: Utilities Operated By City And Municipal Authority
8-1-2: Operation Of Municipal Utility Systems
8-1-3: Use Of Municipal Utility Systems
8-1-4: Turning On Or Off Utilities
8-1-5: Delinquent Utility Bills; Service Discontinued
8-1-6: Maintenance Of Service Pipes; Wasting Water
8-1-7: City Not Responsible For Utility Interruption
8-1-8: Tampering With Fire Hydrants; Damaging Property
8-1-9: Unlawful Service Connection/Theft Of Services; Damaging Public Utilities
8-1-10: Penalty
8-1-1: UTILITIES OPERATED BY CITY AND MUNICIPAL AUTHORITY:
   A.   Services Provided By City: The city provides water, sewer, electric and
solid waste services for the residents of the city.
   B.   Systems Leased To Municipal Authority: All utility systems are owned by
the city, and are leased to the Marlow municipal authority.
   C.   Operation Through Trust: Said trust shall have control over the
operation, maintenance and administration of said systems and services. (Ord.
325, 6-29-1993)
8-1-2: OPERATION OF MUNICIPAL UTILITY SYSTEMS:
   A.   Responsibility; Powers: The operations of the municipal water, sewer,
solid waste and electrical systems shall be the responsibility of the Marlow
municipal authority. Said authority shall have the power to establish fees,
rates, deposits, charges and such other rules and regulations as may be
necessary for the efficient operation of these systems.
   B.   Administrative Processes Combined: Administrative processes for all
systems may be combined for more efficient operation, at the discretion of the
city council and the Marlow municipal authority board.
   C.   Application Of City Ordinances: City ordinances relating to these
utility systems shall be applicable, whenever possible, to all utility systems.
(Ord. 325, 6-29-1993)
8-1-3: USE OF MUNICIPAL UTILITY SYSTEMS:
   A.   Water And Sewer Systems: Every residential inhabitant within the
corporate limits of the city, and every commercial or business entity or
enterprise who may practically do so, shall secure all of its potable water
requirements from the water system owned by the city and leased to the Marlow
municipal authority, and connect to the sanitary sewer system owned by the
city, and leased to the Marlow municipal authority, and not otherwise dispose
of sewage, unless it is impossible or not feasible to do so. (Ord. 325, 6-29-
1993)
   B.   Electrical And Solid Waste Collection Systems: Every resident within
the corporate limits of the city, and every commercial or industrial
establishment, shall utilize the municipal electrical and solid waste
collection and disposal systems of the city, unless it is impossible to do so.
(1985 Code § 16-3)
8-1-4: TURNING ON OR OFF UTILITIES:
   A.   Requirements For Turning On: It shall be unlawful for any person to
turn the utility on to any premises from any municipal system, without written
permission of the city or the Marlow municipal authority, through the office of
the city clerk. Utilities shall not be turned on until any and all deposits and
charges have been paid. The city clerk or the designated agent of the Marlow
municipal authority shall see that the utility is turned on when all
requirements for service have been complied with.
   B.   Turning On After Turn Off By City: When a utility has been turned off
by city personnel, it shall not be turned on again without written permission
of the city clerk or the designated agent of the Marlow municipal authority.
   C.   Turning Off For Conservation: The city reserves the right to cut off
water or electric service to any customer when necessary to conserve water or
electricity, to protect life or property, or to repair or improve the systems.
(1985 Code § 16-155)
8-1-5: DELINQUENT UTILITY BILLS; SERVICE DISCONTINUED:
A person owing delinquent city utility bills or other charges in connection
with any municipal utility system shall not be extended additional services
until such bills and charges have been paid. (1985 Code § 16-156)
8-1-6: MAINTENANCE OF SERVICE PIPES; WASTING WATER:
All customers using municipal utilities shall keep their service pipes and
other apparatus in good repair and in proper operation, and shall not
unnecessarily waste water nor contribute to unsanitary conditions. (Ord. 325,
6-29-1993)
8-1-7: CITY NOT RESPONSIBLE FOR UTILITY INTERRUPTION:
The city shall not be responsible for any damages due to stoppage or
interruption of any utility or service. (1985 Code § 16-158)
8-1-8: TAMPERING WITH FIRE HYDRANTS; DAMAGING PROPERTY:
   A.   Fire Hydrants:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person, unless duly authorized, to
open, turn on or off, interfere with, attach any pipe or hose to, or connect
anything with, any fire hydrant belonging to the city.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person to, in any manner, obstruct
access to any fire hydrant by placing around or thereon brick, lumber, dirt or
other thing. (1985 Code § 16-160)
   B.   Damaging Property: It shall be unlawful for any person to damage,
destroy, obstruct or tamper with any pipes, lines, meters or other equipment or
property which is a part of any municipal utility system. (Ord. 325, 6-29-1993)
8-1-9: UNLAWFUL SERVICE CONNECTION/THEFT OF SERVICES; DAMAGING PUBLIC
UTILITIES:
   A.   Unlawful Service Connection/Theft Of Services:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to connect or attach any kind of
pipe, wire or other contrivance to any pipe, line, wire or other conductor
carrying gas, water, electricity, telephone or cablevision and belonging to a
public utility (whether publicly or privately owned), in such a manner as to
enable that person or any other person to consume or use the gas, water,
electricity, telephone or cablevision without its passing through the meter or
in any other way so as to evade payment therefor.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly take, receive, use
or convert to such person's own use, or the use of another, any electricity,
water or natural gas which has not been measured or any telephone or cable
television service which has not been authorized.
   B.   Damaging Utility Properties: It shall also be unlawful for any person
to damage, molest, tamper with, obstruct or destroy any pipe, line, wire, meter
or other part of any public utility, including telegraph, telephone and
cablevision systems. (Ord. 403, 5-29-2012)
8-1-10: PENALTY:
Every person who violates any provision of this chapter, or of any ordinance,
code or standard adopted by this title, or maintains or permits to continue any
situation defined by this chapter as unlawful, shall be guilty of an offense
and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to penalty as provided in
section
1-5-1 of this code. Every day upon which a violation continues shall be deemed
a separate offense. (1985 Code § 16-175; amd. 2004 Code)
CHAPTER 2
WATER SYSTEM
SECTION:
8-2-1: Water Connections; Compliance Required
8-2-2: Mandatory Use Of Water System
8-2-3: Application For Water Service
8-2-4: Fees, Rates And Charges
8-2-5: Billing; Delinquency Procedure
8-2-6: Unit Connection Limitations
8-2-7: Turning On Water
8-2-8: Water Turned Off By City; Turn On Fee
8-2-9: Fluoride Levels
8-2-10: Water Sprinkler System Installations
8-2-11: Backflow Preventers Installed In Sprinkler Systems
8-2-12: Curb Stops
8-2-13: Tampering With Or Injuring Water System
8-2-14: Penalty
8-2-1: WATER CONNECTIONS; COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
   A.   Compliance With City Regulations: It shall be unlawful for any person,
firm or corporation to make a connection to the municipal water system without
first complying with all applicable provisions of this code and all related
resolutions and requirements of the Marlow municipal authority. (1985 Code §
16-10)
   B.   Connections Outside City: Water connections outside the city limits
must comply with Oklahoma department of environmental quality ground water
rules, and no privately owned water wells shall be cross connected to any water
lines from city meters. (2004 Code)
8-2-2: MANDATORY USE OF WATER SYSTEM:
   A.   Connection Required; Responsibility For Costs: The owners of all
houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment,
education, recreation or other purposes situated within the city, and abutting
on any street, alley or right of way in which there is now located, or may in
the future be located, a municipal water line, are hereby required, at their
expense, to connect their facility with the proper city water line (in
accordance with all city and state requirements) and pay all city fees and use
charges therefor, within one hundred twenty (120) days after the date of
official city notice to do so; provided, that the city water line is within
three hundred feet (300') of the property line.
   B.   Private Water Well: It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or
establish a private water well within the city to serve a facility. (1985 Code
§ 16-11; amd. 2004 Code)
   C.   Application For Connection; Payment Of Fee: No unauthorized person
shall make any connection to any city water line without first having made
application therefor to the city clerk and the Marlow municipal authority, and
without first having paid the established fee.
   D.   Exceptions:
      1.   Where a city water line does not lie within three hundred feet
(300') of the property line, or is not scheduled to be placed within three
hundred feet (300') of the property line in the near future (one to 5 years),
an individual may utilize or establish a private water well without connection
to the municipal water system and, therefore, without payment of the municipal
water system fees and charges.
      2.   The requirements of this section shall not apply to persons
currently being served directly by an existing rural water district. (1985 Code
§ 16-11)
8-2-3: APPLICATION FOR WATER SERVICE:
Any person desiring to secure water from the municipal system shall make an
application therefor to the Marlow municipal authority, through the city clerk,
on an application form to be provided by said city clerk. The applicant shall
give such reasonable information as the city clerk may request. He shall state
in the application that he will abide by all ordinances, rules and regulations
governing the water service of the city. (1985 Code § 16-13)
8-2-4: FEES, RATES AND CHARGES:
   A.   Water Tap Fee: The charge for making a water tap shall be determined by
motion or resolution adopted by the city council and the Marlow municipal
authority. (1985 Code § 16-14)
   B.   Deposit For Water Service: An applicant for water service shall make a
deposit, the amount of which shall be determined by motion or resolution
adopted by the city council and the Marlow municipal authority. An applicant
shall not be granted such service until he has paid to the Marlow municipal
authority, through the city clerk, such deposit. The deposit shall serve as a
guarantee for the payment of charges for water service and other amounts owed
to the city in connection with such services. When a customer's service is
discontinued, the deposit, or any part of such amount deposited which remains
after all such charges and amounts due the city have been satisfied, shall be
returned to the customer. (1985 Code § 16-15)
   C.   Water Rates: The water rates to be charged for water from the municipal
water system shall be prescribed by motion or resolution adopted by the city
council and the Marlow municipal authority. The rates may be classified by
whether the water is used by residential customers or commercial customers, by
customers within or without the city, and/or by other reasonable
classifications. (1985 Code § 16-18)
8-2-5: BILLING; DELINQUENCY PROCEDURE:
   A.   Due Date; Delinquency Procedure; Time Of Payment: All bills for water
service shall be due and payable on the first day of the calendar month
following the service month when the service was rendered. Bills shall become
delinquent if not paid on or before the tenth day of the month in which they
become due, and the service will be shut off after reasonable notice. (1985
Code § 16-19; amd. 2004 Code)
   B.   Bills Rendered When Service Discontinued: Bills rendered when service
is discontinued shall be due and payable at the time the bills are presented or
sent to the customer. (1985 Code § 16-19)
8-2-6: UNIT CONNECTION LIMITATIONS:
   A.   Not more than one unit (house, etc.) may be connected per meter and
sewer tap.
   B.   No customer shall make or permit to be made any subsidiary connection
of another's unit with his water service. (1985 Code § 16-16)
8-2-7: TURNING ON WATER:
It shall be unlawful for any person to turn the water on to any premises from
the municipal water system, except by permission of the Marlow municipal
authority. Water shall not be turned on until the plumbing has been inspected
and approved by Marlow municipal authority or the city building inspector, and
until any and all deposits and charges have been paid. The city will see that
the water is turned on when all requirements for service have been complied
with. (1985 Code § 16-17)
8-2-8: WATER TURNED OFF BY CITY; TURN ON FEE:
   A.   Turning Off Water:
      1.   Water may be cut off and service discontinued for any user for any
of the following reasons:
         a.   Violation of any ordinance or resolution provision relating to
the water system, or violation of any ordinance or resolution provision or any
provision of any code adopted by reference relating to water and sanitary
plumbing; or
         b.   Failure to pay a water bill or other proper charge in connection
with the water system by the time specified by ordinance or resolution.
      2.   Water may also be cut off for any act or omission in regard to the
water system or sanitary sewer system, the use of water, or the disposal of
liquid wastes, which jeopardizes the public health or safety, creates a public
nuisance, or interferes with the rights of others. (1985 Code § 16-20)
   B.   Turning Water On After Turn Off; Charge: When a customer's water
service has been cut off because of delinquency or act or omission of the
customer, as provided by ordinance or resolution, it may be turned on again
only when all charges have been paid or other change in the conditions justify
it. A charge shall be made for turning the water on again during normal working
hours, and a separate charge shall be made for turning water on again after
normal working hours. Said charges shall be set by resolution of the city
council. (1985 Code § 16-21; amd. 2004 Code)
8-2-9: FLUORIDE LEVELS:
In order to protect the health and welfare of the citizens of the city, the
quantity of fluoride in the public water supply shall be controlled in such
manner that the amount present in the water served to the public shall be in
conformity with the policy, and subsequent changes thereto, established by the
Oklahoma department of environmental quality. (1985 Code § 16-22; amd. 2004
Code)
8-2-10: WATER SPRINKLER SYSTEM INSTALLATIONS:
   A.   Permit Required: Before individuals or companies install a sprinkler
system, a permit must be obtained at city hall.
   B.   Inspection: An inspection must be done by the city before said
sprinkler system is connected to the city water supply. (2004 Code)
8-2-11: BACKFLOW PREVENTERS INSTALLED IN SPRINKLER SYSTEMS:
   A.   Definition: As used herein, a "backflow preventer" is defined as a
valve or series of valves that, in the opinion of the city building inspector
or the designated representative of the Marlow municipal authority, will
prevent the backflow of water and contaminants from a lawn sprinkler system
into the water system network from which the water originally entered the lawn
sprinkler system.
   B.   Placement: The backflow preventer shall be placed at the beginning of
the lawn sprinkler system, immediately after the system branches off the
service line, and approved by the city building inspector or the designated
representative of the Marlow municipal authority, before the system is placed
in operation.
   C.   Design Of System: The lawn sprinkler system shall not be used for the
delivery of water to any external faucet or outlet other than the lawn
sprinklers themselves, and the system shall be designed and installed so that
no use of the water entering the lawn sprinkler system may be had other than
the release of water through the installed sprinkler heads. (1985 Code § 16-23)
8-2-12: CURB STOPS:
   A.   Installation: On all service pipes from the water main to the water
meter, there shall be installed by, and at the cost of, the Marlow municipal
authority, a curb stop whereby the city may shut off or turn on the flow of
water through the meter.
   B.   Repairs Of Service Pipes And Curb Stops: All repairs of service pipes
and curb stops, when the repairs are made necessary by the acts or omissions of
property owners or third persons not employed or contracted for by the Marlow
municipal authority, shall be made by, and at the expense of, the owners of the
premises served. In the event such repairs are made by the property owners, the
repairs shall be approved by the city building inspector or the designated
representative of the Marlow municipal authority. The city may, in case of an
emergency, repair any service pipe or curb stop and if this is done, the cost
of such repair work shall be repaid to the city by the owner of the premises
served, according to a schedule of repairs and services adopted by the city
council and the Marlow municipal authority. (1985 Code § 16-24)
8-2-13: TAMPERING WITH OR INJURING WATER SYSTEM:
It shall be unlawful for any person to injure or deface, or in any way tamper
with, any portion of the municipal water system, or to turn the water off or on
from any main at any time or place, unless he is duly authorized so to do by
the city, and the Marlow municipal authority. (1985 Code § 16-12)
8-2-14: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-5-1 of this code. (2004 Code)
CHAPTER 3
SEWER SYSTEM
SECTION:
8-3-1: Use Of Sewer System; Compliance Required
8-3-2: Mandatory Sewer Connections
8-3-3: Private Sewage Disposal Facilities
8-3-4: New Sewers And Connections
8-3-5: User Charge Determination
8-3-6: Billing; Delinquency Procedure
8-3-7: Prohibited Sewer Discharges
8-3-8: Penalties
8-3-9: Sewer Cleanout Covers Required
8-3-1: USE OF SEWER SYSTEM; COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to make any connection
to the municipal sewer system without first complying with all applicable
provisions of this code and all other requirements of the city, or the Marlow
municipal authority. (Ord. 368, 2-6-2002)
8-3-2: MANDATORY SEWER CONNECTIONS:
   A.   Connection Of Facilities To City Sewer: The owners of all houses,
buildings or property used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other
purposes, situated within the corporate limits of the city, and abutting on any
street, alley or right of way in which there is located a public sanitary sewer
of the city, are hereby required, at their own expense, to install suitable
toilet facilities therein, and to have such facilities connected directly with
the proper public sewer within sixty (60) days after the date of official
notice to do so; provided, that such public sewer is within three hundred feet
(300') of the property line.
   B.   Service Of Notice: Said notice, as provided for in subsection A of this
section, shall be served by any designated agent of the city by delivering a
true and correct copy to the property owner, or leaving the same at his usual
place of residence with a member of his family over the age of fifteen (15)
years, or if such owner cannot be found, by posting a copy of such notice at
the front entrance of the building involved.
   C.   Failure To Comply; Discontinuance Of Service: Any person who shall
fail, neglect or refuse to comply with the terms of this section after having
been notified so to do as provided herein shall be guilty of an offense. In the
event of a continuous violation of this section by any property owner, the city
may discontinue the furnishing of water to such property owner, until such time
as a proper sewer connection has been made. (Ord. 368, 2-6-2002)
8-3-3: PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL FACILITIES:
   A.   Privies, Septic Tanks Prohibited; Exception: Except as hereinafter
provided in this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to construct or
maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility
intended to be used for the disposal of sewage, within the corporate limits of
the city.
   B.   Compliance With State And Local Requirements:
      1.   Where a connection to a public sanitary sewer line is not required
under the provisions of section
8-3-2 of this chapter, a private septic tank or cesspool facility for sewage
disposal may be constructed and maintained, provided it is constructed and
maintained under the rules and regulations of the local and county health
officer, and in compliance with the recommendations and requirements of the
Oklahoma state department of environmental quality.
      2.   No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any
public sewer or natural outlet, nor shall any septic system be installed
without having a successful percolation test made prior to installation.
   C.   Maintenance In Sanitary Manner: The owner of private septic tanks or
cesspools shall operate and maintain the same in a sanitary manner at all
times, at no expense to the city, and no statement contained in this chapter
shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be
imposed by the local, county or state health officer.
   D.   Availability Of Public Sewer; Connection Required: At such time as a
public sewer becomes available to a property served by a septic tank or
cesspool, a direct connection shall be made to such public sewer in compliance
with section
8-3-2 of this chapter, and the septic tank or cesspool shall immediately be
abandoned and filled with suitable material. (Ord. 368, 2-6-2002)
8-3-4: NEW SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS:
   A.   Connections; International Plumbing Code Compliance: The connection of
the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of
the international plumbing code and other applicable rules and regulations of
the city.
   B.   Design And Construction; State Requirements: All new sanitary sewage
works shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the requirements and
regulations of the Oklahoma state department of environmental quality.
   C.   Availability; Connection To Public Sewer: When a public sewer becomes
available (within 300 feet), the building sewer shall be connected to said
sewer within sixty (60) days. (Ord. 368, 2-6-2002)
8-3-5: USER CHARGE DETERMINATION:
Charges for the use of the city owned wastewater treatment (sanitary sewer)
system shall be set by resolution of the mayor and city council. The mayor and
council shall, from time to time, review the user charges and may change those
charges by resolution of the mayor and council. (Ord. 368, 2-6-2002)
8-3-6: BILLING; DELINQUENCY PROCEDURE:
   A.   Billing:
      1.   Users will be billed on a monthly basis, with payment due ten (10)
days after the date of billing.
      2.   Users on metered water service will be billed on the same notice as
water charges and will be designated as a separate entry. (Ord. 368, 2-6-2002)
      3.   Users of the wastewater system not on metered water service will be
billed monthly on an individual notice for wastewater service at the rate
established by the city council and Marlow municipal authority.
   B.   Delinquencies; Notice Of Termination:
      1.   All bills for sewer service shall be due and payable on the first
day of the calendar month following the service month when the service was
rendered. Bills shall become delinquent if not paid on or before the tenth day
of the month in which they become due, and the service will be shut off after
reasonable notice.
      2.   The city council and Marlow municipal authority will utilize the
municipal law enforcement system to assist, as required, in the control and
management of the user charge system. (Ord. 368, 2-6-2002; amd. 2004 Code)
8-3-7: PROHIBITED SEWER DISCHARGES:
   A.   Injurious Discharges: No person may discharge to public sewers any
waste which, by itself or by interaction with other wastes, may:
      1.   Injure or interfere with wastewater treatment processes or
facilities;
      2.   Constitute a hazard to humans or animals;
      3.   Cause a violation of effluent or water quality limitations in the
receiving waters of the wastewater treatment plant effluent; or
      4.   Preclude the selection of the most cost effective alternative for
wastewater treatment and sludge disposal.
   B.   Exceptions: All discharges shall be prohibited except those that meet
the criteria for domestic wastewater. BOD concentration shall not exceed three
hundred milligrams per liter (300 mg/l)*. SS shall not exceed three hundred
milligrams per liter (300 mg/l)*. (*Maximum limit for average domestic
wastewater.)
   C.   Industrial Discharges: All industrial discharges are prohibited. At the
present time there are no industrial users in the city. If an industrial user
should desire to locate in the city and make use of the sewer system, an
industrial user system will be initiated in accordance with EPA and state
regulations at that time to compensate for its use of the system.
   D.   New Connections From Inflow Sources: Any new connections from inflow
sources into the sanitary sewer portions of the sewer system shall be
prohibited. (Ord. 368, 2-6-2002)
8-3-8: PENALTIES:
   A.   Penalty For Prohibited Discharges:
      1.   Penalty Imposed: A person who continues prohibited discharges is
guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, is subject to penalty as
provided in section
1-5-1 of this code for each act of violation and for each day of violation.
      2.   Criminal Or Civil Remedies: In addition to proceeding under
authority of subsection A1 of this section, the city is entitled to pursue all
other criminal and civil remedies to which it is entitled under authority of
statutes or other ordinances against a person continuing prohibited discharges.
      3.   Right To Terminate Service: The city reserves the right to terminate
service, after reasonable notice, to any customer that fails to pay bills when
due or discharges any prohibited wastes into the sewer system. (Ord. 368, 2-6-
2002; amd. 2004 Code)
   B.   Other Violations: Any person violating the provisions of this chapter,
except for violations covered by subsection A of this section, and, upon
conviction thereof, shall be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-5-1 of this code. (2004 Code)
8-3-9: SEWER CLEANOUT COVERS REQUIRED:
   A.   Cleanout Cover Required: All sewer cleanouts of any house, building or
property used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes
shall be covered with a suitable cover or plug designed to prevent inflow or
infiltration generated by sources outside said house, building or property from
entering the sanitary sewer connection of such house, building or property.
   B.   Service Of Notice: If the city of Marlow determines that a sewer
cleanout does not have a suitable cover or plug, the owner of the property or
other responsible party shall be notified that he/she has ten (10) days to
correct the situation. Said notice shall be served by a designated agent of the
city by delivering a true and correct copy to the property owner or leaving the
same at his/her usual place of residence with a member of the family over the
age of fifteen (15) years, or by posting a copy of the notice at the front
entrance of the building involved if the owner cannot be found.
   C.   Failure To Comply: Any person who shall fail, neglect or refuse to
comply with the terms of this section after having been notified to do so shall
be guilty of an offense and may be fined as provided in this chapter, or the
city may discontinue water service to the property until the situation is
corrected. (Ord. 415, 6-28-2016)
CHAPTER 4
ELECTRIC SYSTEM
SECTION:
8-4-1: System Operated By City And Municipal Authority
8-4-2: Application For Service
8-4-3: Fees, Rates And Charges
8-4-4: Billing; Delinquency Procedure
8-4-5: Unit Connection Limitations
8-4-6: Turning On Electricity
8-4-7: Electricity Turned Off By City; Turn On Charge
8-4-8: Penalty
8-4-1: SYSTEM OPERATED BY CITY AND MUNICIPAL AUTHORITY:
The municipal electric system is a public utility owned and operated by the
city, leased to the Marlow municipal authority, and under the control of the
electrical and utility superintendents. It is the responsibility of the Marlow
municipal authority and the city council to see that it is operated in a
businesslike manner and in accordance with ordinance and resolution provisions
and other policies adopted by the Marlow municipal authority and the city
council. (1985 Code § 16-60)
8-4-2: APPLICATION FOR SERVICE:
Any person desiring to secure electricity from the municipal system shall make
an application therefor to the Marlow municipal authority, through the city
clerk, on an application form to be provided by the city. The applicant shall
give such reasonable information as the city clerk may request. He shall state
in the application that he will abide by all ordinances, resolutions, rules and
regulations governing the electric service of the city. (1985 Code § 16-61)
8-4-3: FEES, RATES AND CHARGES:
   A.   Deposit Required:
      1.   An applicant for electric service shall make a deposit, the amount
of which shall be determined by motion or resolution adopted by the Marlow
municipal authority and the city council. An applicant shall not be granted
such service until he has paid to the Marlow municipal authority, through the
city clerk, such deposit.
      2.   The deposit shall serve as a guarantee for the payment of charges
for electric service and other amounts owed in connection with such service.
When a customer's service is discontinued, the deposit or any part of such
amount deposited which remains after all such charges and amounts due the city
have been satisfied, shall be returned to the customer. (1985 Code § 16-62)
   B.   Electric Rates:
      1.   The electric rates to be charged for electricity from the municipal
electric system shall be prescribed by motion or resolution adopted by the
Marlow municipal authority or the city council.
      2.   The rates may be classified by whether the electricity is used by
residential customers or commercial customers, by customers within or without
the city, and/or by other reasonable classifications. (1985 Code § 16-65)
8-4-4: BILLING; DELINQUENCY PROCEDURE:
   A.   Due Date; Delinquency Procedure; Time Of Payment: All bills for
electric service shall be due and payable on the first day of the calendar
month following the service month when the service was rendered. They shall
become delinquent if not paid on or before the tenth day of the month in which
they become due, and the service will be shut off after reasonable notice.
(1985 Code § 16-66; amd. 2004 Code)
   B.   Bills Rendered When Service Discontinued: Bills rendered when service
is discontinued, shall be due and payable at the time the bills are presented
or sent to the customer. (1985 Code § 16-66)
8-4-5: UNIT CONNECTION LIMITATIONS:
   A.   Not more than one unit (house, etc.) may be connected per meter.
   B.   No customer shall make or permit to be made any subsidiary connection
of another's unit with his electric service. (1985 Code § 16-63)
8-4-6: TURNING ON ELECTRICITY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to turn the electricity on to any premises
from the municipal electric system, except by permission of the Marlow
municipal authority. Electricity shall not be turned on until the electrical
wiring has been inspected and approved by the Marlow municipal authority or the
city building inspector, and until any and all deposits and charges have been
paid. The city will see that the electricity is turned on when all requirements
for service have been complied with. (1985 Code § 16-64)
8-4-7: ELECTRICITY TURNED OFF BY CITY; TURN ON CHARGE:
   A.   Turning Off Electricity:
      1.   Electricity may be cut off and service discontinued for any user for
any of the following reasons:
         a.   Violation of any ordinance or resolution provision relating to
the electric system, or violation of any ordinance or resolution provision or
any provision of any code adopted by reference relating to electrical
installations, as the case may be; or
         b.   Failure to pay an electric bill or other proper charge in
connection with the electric system by the time specified by resolution and/or
ordinance.
      2.   Electricity may also be cut off for any act or omission in regard to
any municipal utility system which jeopardizes the public health or safety,
creates a public nuisance, or interferes with the rights of others. (1985 Code
§ 16-67)
   B.   Turning Electricity On After Turn Off; Charge: When a customer's
electric service has been cut off because of delinquency or act or omission of
the customer, it may be turned on again only when all charges have been paid or
other change in the conditions justify it. A charge shall be made for turning
the electricity on again during normal working hours, and for turning
electricity on again after normal working hours or on weekends or on holidays,
in accordance with fees established by ordinance or resolution. (Ord. 325, 6-
29-1993)
8-4-8: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-5-1 of this code. (2004 Code)
CHAPTER 5
SOLID WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL SYSTEM
SECTION:
8-5-1: System Operated By City And Municipal Authority
8-5-2: Purpose And Policy
8-5-3: Definitions
8-5-4: Duty To Request Garbage Service
8-5-5: Garbage And Refuse Accumulations; Container Requirements
8-5-6: Collection Of Garbage And Refuse
8-5-7: Refuse Collection Business Permit
8-5-8: Service Collection Fees
8-5-9: Billing; Delinquencies
8-5-10: Inspection Of Premises
8-5-11: Disposal Of Dead Animals And Rubbish
8-5-12: Restrictions Concerning Refuse And Containers
8-5-13: Burning Of Solid Waste
8-5-14: Scavenging Prohibited
8-5-15: Penalty
8-5-1: SYSTEM OPERATED BY CITY AND MUNICIPAL AUTHORITY:
   A.   City Function; Leased To Authority: The collection and disposal of
garbage, trash, refuse and other solid waste is hereby declared to be a
municipal function of the city, and leased to the Marlow municipal authority as
a protection of the public health.
   B.   Enforcement: The police powers of the city shall be invoked when
necessary for the enforcement of this chapter.
   C.   Refuse Collection And Disposal Method: In addition, the city may
collect and dispose of refuse, as it deems necessary; provided, that such
disposal shall be an approved method of incineration (not open burning) or by
landfill and daily cover. (Ord. 325, 6-29-1993)
8-5-2: PURPOSE AND POLICY:
It is the purpose of this chapter and it is hereby declared to be the policy of
the city, and the Marlow municipal authority, pursuant to the authority of the
Oklahoma solid waste management act (27A Oklahoma Statutes section 2-10-101 et
seq., inclusive, and as amended), to regulate the collection and disposal of
solid wastes in a manner that will protect the public health and welfare,
prevent air and water pollution, prevent the spread of disease and the creation
of nuisances, conserve the natural resources, and enhance and preserve the
beauty and quality of the community's environment. (Ord. 325, 6-29-1993; amd.
2004 Code)
8-5-3: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed
to them in this section:
   REFUSE: Tree trimmings, junked building and roofing materials, manufacturing
waste, rocks, dirt and other waste material not defined as "solid waste" or
"trash".
   SANITATION SUPERINTENDENT: The municipal sanitation superintendent of the
city, or his authorized agent.
   SOLID WASTE: Shall include all putrescible and nonputrescible refuse in
solid or semisolid form, including, but not limited to, garbage, refuse,
rubbish, ashes or incinerator residue, street refuse, dead animals, demolition
wastes, construction wastes, solid or semisolid commercial and industrial
wastes and hazardous wastes (including explosives, pathological wastes,
chemical wastes, herbicide and pesticide wastes).
   SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM: The entire process of storage, collection,
transportation, processing and burying solid wastes at or in a site approved by
the Oklahoma state department of environmental quality.
   TRASH: Paper, rags, containers of paper, tin cans, yard and house sweepings
and all other household waste, but not tree trimmings, building and
manufacturing waste, sewage and rocks, raw dirt, rainwater and other liquid
refuse properly disposable through the sanitary sewers of the city. (1985 Code
§ 16-82; amd. 2004 Code)
8-5-4: DUTY TO REQUEST GARBAGE SERVICE:
To assist in maintaining the general sanitation of the city, it shall be the
duty of every person occupying or having control of the occupancy of any
premises located on a regularly established garbage route to notify the city
clerk at the beginning of such occupancy, and request, accept and use the
garbage pick up and collection services; provided however, that failure of any
owner, rental agent or occupant of such premises to make such request shall not
prevent, nor in any way impair or impede, the city from adding the address of
such premises to the proper garbage collection route records, providing such
service and otherwise enforcing, by appropriate action, the regulatory measures
herein prescribed and causing the fees or charges therefor to be paid. (1985
Code § 16-89)
8-5-5: GARBAGE AND REFUSE ACCUMULATIONS; CONTAINER REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Containers Required; Specifications; Location:
      1.   It shall be the duty of every person, firm or corporation owning,
managing, operating, leasing or renting any premises or any place where garbage
or rubbish accumulates to provide for, and at all times to maintain in good
order and repair, on any said premises, a portable container or containers for
refuse which shall be made of galvanized metal or equivalent, not easily
corrodible, rodentproof and flyproof, with a tight fitting lid which shall not
be removed except when depositing or removing the contents of the receptacle,
and with handles on the sides, and of sufficient capacity and in sufficient
numbers to accommodate and securely keep all of the garbage and rubbish that
may accumulate between collections; provided, that each container shall have a
capacity as specified from time to time by the city council. All containers
shall be kept clean and free from the accumulation of any substance remaining
attached to the inside of the container which would attract flies, mosquitoes
or any other insects. All container lids shall be chained or fastened securely
at all times to a stationary object.
      2.   All containers and grounds immediately around same shall be kept in
a safe and sanitary condition at all times, and kept in suitable racks. (1985
Code § 16-83; amd. 2004 Code)
   B.   Refuse Bundled Or Bagged:
      1.   All ordinary accumulations of rubbish such as tree limbs, paper
boxes, scrap lumber, bricks, leaves, grass clippings, etc., which cannot be
conveniently placed in the containers required under this chapter shall be
gathered together in bundles weighing fifty (50) pounds or less and no item in
the bundle shall be longer than four feet (4'). Bundles shall be secured with
heavy string, rope, etc., so that the binding will not break if used to pick up
the bundle.
      2.   Plastic bags may also be used but must be securely tied at the
opening and the contents shall be of a weight and composition so as not to
cause the bag to break open when lifted by the top.
      3.   Bundles and bags shall be placed immediately adjacent to a public
street or alley and not on the private property side of any fence or other
barrier, and shall not be stacked in such a location or manner as to hide or
obstruct any utility meter, pole, can, lid, or other device.
      4.   Rubble and rubbish not conforming to this subsection will be handled
as outlined elsewhere in this chapter. (Ord. 308, 10-25-1988)
   C.   Removal Of Receptacles After Pick Up: Every person, firm or corporation
owning, managing, operating, leasing, or renting any premises or any place
where garbage or rubbish accumulates shall remove trash receptacles from their
collection location, as specified in subsection A2 of this section, to a
storage location not visible from the front of the premises within twelve (12)
hours after trash is collected by the city or its authorized representative.
(Ord. 360, 8-31-1999)
8-5-6: COLLECTION OF GARBAGE AND REFUSE:
The city, or its authorized representatives, shall collect from the containers
required under this chapter from the residential areas of the city and from the
commercial and industrial operations and all food establishments of the city
all garbage and rubbish as often as is necessary to ensure sanitary conditions;
provided, that it shall be the duty of any person in possession or control of
any premises to place the containers required in this chapter in a location
easily accessible to the collector, as directed in this chapter, as determined
by the sanitation superintendent. (Ord. 308, 10-25-1988; amd. 2004 Code)
8-5-7: REFUSE COLLECTION BUSINESS PERMIT:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to engage in the
business of refuse collection or refuse disposal for compensation in the city,
unless authorized by the city. (1985 Code § 16-85; amd. 2004 Code)
8-5-8: SERVICE COLLECTION FEES:
   A.   Monthly Residential Charge: There shall be charged, assessed and
collected from each residential unit within the city limits, a monthly amount
established by the city council. (1985 Code § 16-88)
   B.   Commercial And Industrial Units: There shall be charged, assessed and
collected from each commercial or industrial unit within the city limits, using
the refuse service of the city, a fee which shall be established by the city
council. These fees shall be established using the following criteria:
      1.   Volume of refuse collected;
      2.   Number of weekly collections requested; and
      3.   Time and difficulty involved in making collection. (Ord. 321, 10-29-
1991)
8-5-9: BILLING; DELINQUENCIES:
   A.   Rendition With Other Utility Bills: All bills for solid waste
collection and disposal service charges may be included on other city utility
bills and no payment shall be accepted except for the full amount billed for
all services.
   B.   Delinquencies: Delinquent solid waste service bills shall carry the
same due dates, grace periods and penalties as other utility bills. (1985 Code
§ 16-90)
8-5-10: INSPECTION OF PREMISES:
It shall be the duty of the city health official to make all necessary
inspections and investigations of any and all premises to see that the terms of
this chapter, and all regulations of the city, are complied with. (1985 Code §
16-87)
8-5-11: DISPOSAL OF DEAD ANIMALS AND RUBBISH:
   A.   Carcasses Of Animals: Carcasses of animals such as cows, horses and
mules shall be removed and disposed of at the expense of the owner or person
having same in charge and by the method directed by the city health official.
   B.   Heavy, Bulky Accumulations: Heavy accumulations such as brush, broken
concrete, ashes, sand or gravel, automobile frames, dead trees, and other
bulky, heavy materials shall be disposed of at the expense of the owner or
person controlling same under the direction of the sanitation superintendent.
   C.   Manure, Waste Oils, Hazardous Materials: Manure from cow lots, horse
stables, poultry yards, pigeon lofts and other animal or fowl pens, and waste
oils from garages or filling stations, or materials considered hazardous and/or
dangerous, shall be removed and disposed of at the expense of the person
controlling same in the manner and by the method directed by the city health
official. (1985 Code § 16-86)
8-5-12: RESTRICTIONS CONCERNING REFUSE AND CONTAINERS:
   A.   Placing Garbage In Streets, Other Prohibited Places: The placing of
garbage, rubbish or any refuse material in any street or alley within the city
limits, or the disposal of such refuse at any place within the city limits,
except at the municipal disposal site, or at such other place as may be
directed by the city health official, is prohibited.
   B.   Meddling With Refuse Containers: The meddling with refuse containers or
in any way pilfering, scattering contents, or junking in any alley or street
within the city limits is prohibited.
   C.   Method Of Disposal Of Garbage: The disposal of garbage and rubbish
shall be by an approved method of incineration (not open burning) or by
landfill and daily cover. (1985 Code § 16-86)
   D.   Container Use Restricted: Use of refuse containers shall be prohibited
to all except the owner. (2004 Code)
8-5-13: BURNING OF SOLID WASTE:
   A.   Burning Solid Waste: It shall be unlawful for any person to start or
maintain any fire, or cause any fire to be started or maintained, for the
purpose of burning or incinerating any solid waste.
   B.   Incinerators: It shall be unlawful to construct or install, within any
building in the city, an incinerator designed to burn solid wastes. (1985 Code
§ 16-91)
8-5-14: SCAVENGING PROHIBITED:
   A.   Definition: "Scavenging", as used in this section, means the
collecting, hauling, transporting or removing of any material or any residue or
part thereof, of any kind or whatsoever nature, from any dump ground, sanitary
landfill, garbage or trash disposal facility, or sewage disposal facility,
provided or maintained by the city or the Marlow municipal authority, for such
purposes.
   B.   Prohibition: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation,
unless expressly licensed or permitted by the city or the Marlow municipal
authority, to enter upon any dump ground, sanitary landfill, garbage or trash
disposal facility or sewage disposal facility maintained by the city or the
Marlow municipal authority for such purposes, and engage in "scavenging", as
defined herein. (Ord. 314, 8-29-1989)
8-5-15: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction
thereof, be subject to penalty as provided in section
 1-5-1 of this code. (2004 Code)

CHAPTER 1
BUILDING CODES AND REGULATIONS
SECTION:
9-1-1: Construction Codes Adopted
9-1-2: Modifications Of Adopted Codes
9-1-3: Enforcement Of Adopted Codes
9-1-4: Nonliability Of City Officers And Employees
9-1-5: Fire Limits; Regulations
9-1-6: Moving Of Frame Buildings
9-1-7: Smoke Detectors Required In Rental Units
9-1-8: Conduit Required For Underground Wiring
9-1-9: Grease, Oil And Sand Interceptors For Certain Businesses
9-1-10: Penalty
9-1-1: CONSTRUCTION CODES ADOPTED:
   A.   Adoption By Reference: The particular model codes listed below, as
adopted and amended by the Oklahoma Uniform Building Code Commission (the
"OUBCC") in the Oklahoma State Statutes and Oklahoma Administrative Code, are
hereby adopted and incorporated in this code, as if fully set out at length
herein, for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the following
activities carried on within the corporate limits of the City of Marlow,
Oklahoma:
      1.   Building Code: The construction, alteration, removal, demolition,
equipment, use, occupancy, location and maintenance of buildings and
structures:
      International Building Code (IBC), current edition, published by the
International Code Council.
      2.   Existing Building Code: The repair, alteration, addition and change
of occupancy for existing buildings and historic buildings:
      International Existing Building Code (IEBC), current edition, published
by the International Code Council.
      3.   Plumbing Code: The installation or alteration of plumbing and
drainage systems for buildings and structures:
      International Plumbing Code (IPC), current edition, published by the
International Code Council.
      4.   Electrical Code: The installation or alteration of electrical
equipment for buildings or structures:
      National Electric Code (NEC), current edition, published by the National
Fire Protection Association.
      5.   Housing Code: The provisions of basic, minimum housing standards for
the preservation of the health, safety and welfare of occupants:
      International Residential Code (IRC), current edition, published by the
International Code Council.
      6.   Fire Prevention Code: The provision of basic safeguards to life and
property from the hazards of fire and explosion:
      International Fire Code (IFC), current edition, published by the
International Code Council.
      7.   Gas Code: The installation or alteration of gas systems for
buildings or structures:
      International Fuel Gas Code (IFGC), current edition, published by the
International Code Council.
      8.   Energy Conservation Code: The provision of basic standards for
energy conservation in buildings and structures:
      International Energy Conservation Code (IECC), current edition, published
by the International Code Council.
      9.   Mechanical Code: The provision of basic standards for mechanical
installations in buildings and structures:
      International Mechanical Code, current edition, published by the
International Code Council.
      10.   Property Maintenance Code: The provision of basic standards
governing the maintenance of existing buildings:
      International Property Maintenance Code (IMC), current edition, published
by the International Code Council.
   B.   Codes On File:  Three (3) copies of all of the codes referenced in this
section adopted by the city are on file in the office of the City Clerk-
Treasurer.
   C.   Codes In Effect: From the date on which this chapter shall take effect,
the provisions of the codes, as herein modified, shall be controlling in those
areas set forth in section
9-1-2 E. of this chapter, within the corporate limits of the City of Marlow,
Oklahoma.
   D.   Conflicts With City Code: Whenever any provision of any of those model
construction codes adopted by this chapter conflict with this code, the latter
provisions shall govern. (1985 Code § 4-5) (amd. Ord. 426, 11-27-2018)
9-1-2: MODIFICATIONS OF ADOPTED CODES:
   A.   Definitions:
      1.   Wherever the words "City", "Town" or "Municipality" are used in
those codes adopted, it shall mean the city of Marlow, Oklahoma.
      2.   Wherever the words "Inspector", "Building Inspector" or
"Administrative Official" are used in those codes adopted, it shall mean the
city official currently assuming the duties and responsibilities of city
building inspector for the city of Marlow, Oklahoma.
   B.   Official Titles: All official titles used in those codes adopted shall
be interpreted as defined in this city code.
   C.   Penalties: Maximum penalties for violation of provisions of those codes
adopted shall be provided in the "penalty" section of this chapter (section
9-1-10).
   D.   Wood Shingles: Notwithstanding any provisions of any of those codes
adopted by this chapter, wood shingles may be used for roofing.
   E.   Corporate Limits: All limits, except "fire limits", referred to in any
of those codes adopted by this chapter are hereby established as the corporate
limits of the city of Marlow, Oklahoma. (1985 Code § 4-2)
9-1-3: ENFORCEMENT OF ADOPTED CODES:
Any city official or other employee designated by the city administrator shall
be responsible for enforcing the codes adopted by this chapter. Said persons
may bear such titles as "building inspector", "gas inspector", "plumbing
inspector", "electrical inspector", etc., as may be deemed appropriate to
indicate their respective areas of concern, and shall be appointed or
designated by the city administrator. (1985 Code § 4-6; amd. 2004 Code)
9-1-4: NONLIABILITY OF CITY OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES:
   A.   Relief From Personal Liability: Any officer or employee of the city
charged with the enforcement of this chapter and acting in good faith and
without malice, for the city, in the discharge of his duties, shall not thereby
render himself liable personally and he is hereby relieved from all personal
liability for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of
any act or omission required or permitted in the discharge of such duties.
   B.   Defense Of Suits: Any suit brought against any officer or employee
because of such act or omission performed by him in the enforcement of any
provisions of such codes may be defended by the city attorney until the final
termination of the proceedings. (1985 Code § 4-42)
9-1-5: FIRE LIMITS; REGULATIONS:
   A.   Fire Limits Established: The following territory within the corporate
limits (original townsite) of the city shall embrace and constitute the "fire
limits" of the city:

   B.   Construction Limitations:
      1.   Construction Or Moving Of Buildings; Fireproof Walls: It shall
hereafter be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to build, erect,
construct or cause to be built, erected or constructed, or place or move within
the territory described in subsection A of this section, any building or
addition thereto, unless the walls of such building or addition shall be built
or constructed of stone, brick or other noncombustible material.
      2.   Rebuilding Damaged Building: It shall also be unlawful to rebuild
any building which has been more than fifty percent (50%) destroyed by fire,
except as herein stated. (1985 Code § 4-37)
9-1-6: MOVING OF FRAME BUILDINGS 1 :
No frame building shall be moved from without to within the corporate limits of
the city which, by reason of its age, state of repair, condition of wiring or
which, for any other reason, is unfit for human habitation or which might
endanger the public peace, safety, health or welfare. (1985 Code § 4-38)

  9-2A-1 of this title.
9-1-7: SMOKE DETECTORS REQUIRED IN RENTAL UNITS:
   A.   Definition: The term "smoke detector" shall mean a device which detects
particles or products of combustion, other than heat, approved by Underwriter's
Laboratory, Inc., or other comparable testing firm.
   B.   Applicability Of Section: Any building, public or private, other than
single-family dwelling units constructed after the effective date of this
section, shall be subject to the rules and regulations contained in this
section. This includes, but is not limited by reason of enumeration to, the
following: multiple-family dwellings, motels, hotels, nursing homes,
convalescent homes, rooming houses, condominiums, apartments, commercial
establishments, and public buildings of every type.
   C.   Installation Required; Alternative:
      1.   The installation of a minimum of one smoke detector per affected
building is hereby required for all buildings constructed subsequent to the
effective date of this section.
      2.   As an alternative to a smoke detector, a fire detection system may
be installed. No fire detection system shall be installed unless a permit is
issued therefor by the building inspector.
   D.   Occupancy Prohibited Without Smoke Detector: It shall be unlawful for
any person to occupy a building required under this section to have a smoke
detector, or let the same to another for occupancy, which does not have
installed and in operating condition, a smoke detector on each level of said
building.
   E.   Installation In Hallways: In buildings defined in subsection B of this
section, where a common hallway is used, smoke detectors shall be spaced not
more than twenty five feet (25') apart in such hallway.
   F.   Number Of Smoke Detectors: At least one smoke detector shall be
installed per unit. A "unit" is herein defined as a separate and distinct
dwelling unit in a multi-family dwelling and as a separate and distinct public
or commercial establishment in a structure housing more than one public or
commercial establishment.
   G.   Mounting On Wall Or Ceiling: Each required smoke detector shall be
mounted on the ceiling, or a wall not more than twelve inches (12") from the
ceiling.
   H.   Maintenance: It shall be the responsibility of the owner of each
affected building covered by this section to maintain all smoke detectors or
fire detectors in good working order. (1985 Code § 4-43)
9-1-8: CONDUIT REQUIRED FOR UNDERGROUND WIRING:
All new electrical installation and wiring from the power pole to electric
meter shall be enclosed in conduit of PVC pipe schedule 40 for all portions of
the electric line running underground. (Ord. 312, 4-25-1989)
9-1-9: GREASE, OIL AND SAND INTERCEPTORS FOR CERTAIN BUSINESSES:
   A.   Installation Required; Exceptions:
      1.   A grease interceptor shall be installed in the waste line leading
from sinks, drains or other fixtures in restaurants, hotel kitchens, cafeterias
and food processing establishments, and in any bar, lounge, private club or
fountain where food is prepared or served, or where dishes, glasses, pots, pans
or other kitchenwares are washed, or any other establishment where grease or
broken glass can be introduced into the drainage system in quantities that can
effect line stoppage or hinder sewage disposal. Grease, oil and sand
interceptors are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing
grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand or other ingredients
harmful to the building's drainage system, the public sewer or sewage treatment
plant process.
      2.   Interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or
residential dwelling units.
   B.   Maintenance And Operations; Inspection: All interceptors shall be of a
type and capacity as defined in the city's current adopted plumbing code and
shall be approved by the city building inspector. All interceptors shall be
located so as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection.
Such interceptors shall be properly inspected following construction, by the
city building inspector, and shall be maintained by the owner, at his expense,
in continuously efficient operation at all times.
   C.   Avoiding Hazardous Conditions: An oil separator shall be installed in
the drainage system of any establishment where, in the judgement of the city
building inspector, a hazard exists or where oils or other flammables could be
introduced or admitted into the public sewer by accident or otherwise.
   D.   Certain Business Establishments:
      1.   All garages, filling stations and car washes having car wash racks
or facilities shall install combination grit and grease interceptors.
      2.   All commercial laundries shall be equipped with an interceptor
having a removable wire basket or similar device that will prevent strings,
rags, buttons or other materials detrimental to the public sewage system from
passing into the drainage system.
      3.   Bottling plants shall discharge all process wastes into an
interceptor which will provide for the separation of broken glass or other
solids, before discharging liquid wastes into the drainage system.
      4.   Slaughterhouses shall equip all slaughtering room drains with a
separator which shall prevent the discharge of feathers, entrails and other
material likely to clog the drainage system.
   E.   Time Limit For Installations: All existing establishments listed in
subsection A of this section shall have ninety (90) days from the effective
date of this section to install an improved interceptor or separator.
Establishments covered under subsection C of this section will be handled on a
case by case basis to determine whether an oil separator is required. All
establishments covered under subsection A of this section, constructed
henceforth, shall include an approved interceptor. (1985 Code § 4-41)
   F.   Right Of Entry For Inspections: The city building inspector, utilities
superintendent, city administrator, or other official designated by the city
administrator, shall have the right of entry during usual business hours, to
conduct an inspection of an interceptor or separator. (1985 Code § 4-41; amd.
2004 Code)
   G.   Violation; Penalty:
      1.   Notice; Cease Violations: Any person found to be in violation of
this section shall be served with written notice stating the violation and
providing seventy two (72) hours for the satisfactory correction thereof. The
offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently
cease all violations. In the event an establishment is cited with a second
violation within six (6) months of the first, the time allowed for correction
shall be reduced to forty eight (48) hours. A third citation within six (6)
months from the first violation will be cause for the city to immediately
discontinue water service to the establishment for a period of not less than
ten (10) days during which time the offender shall correct the violation. (1985
Code § 4-41)
      2.   Penalty: Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time
limit provided for in subsection G1 of this section, and upon conviction
thereof, shall be subject to penalty as provided in section
9-1-10 of this chapter for each violation. Each day in which any such violation
shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense. (1985 Code § 4-41; amd. 2004
Code)
9-1-10: PENALTY:
Any person, firm or corporation who shall fail to do any thing required by this
chapter or by any code adopted by this chapter, who shall otherwise violate any
provision of this chapter or of any code adopted by this chapter, or who shall
violate any lawful regulation or order made by any of the officers provided for
in this chapter, shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction thereof,
shall be subject to penalty as provided in section
1-5-1 of this code. Each day upon which a violation continues, shall be deemed
a separate offense. (1985 Code § 4-55; amd. 2004 Code)
CHAPTER 2
PERMIT REQUIREMENTS AND REGULATIONS
SECTION:
9-2-1: Building Permit Requirements; Fees
9-2-2: Review Of Building Permit Application; Conditions
9-2-3: Consideration; Permit Issuance Or Denial
9-2-4: Display Of Permit
9-2-5: Failure To Initiate Work
9-2-6: Record Of Permits And Fees
9-2-7: Monitor Utility Hookup Requests
9-2-8: Appeal Building Permit Decisions
9-2-9: Conflicting Provisions
9-2-10: Revocation Of Permit
9-2-11: Penalty
9-2-1: BUILDING PERMIT REQUIREMENTS; FEES:
   A.   Various Permits Required:
      1.   Building Construction, Demolition, Removal: No person shall erect,
enlarge, construct, relocate, substantially improve, repair, place, alter, move
or demolish any building, structure, mobile, modular or manufactured home, or
initiate any other construction without first obtaining a separate building
permit for each such building or structure from the Office of the City Clerk.
      2.   Manmade Changes To Real Estate In Flood Hazard Areas 1 : No manmade
change to improved or unimproved real estate located within a designated flood
hazard area, including, but not limited to, buildings or other structures,
mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavation or drilling operations,
shall be initiated until a separate building permit has been obtained for each
such operation from the Office of the City Clerk.
      3.   Mobile, Manufacturing, Modular Home Placement 2 : No mobile,
manufactured or modular home shall be placed on improved or unimproved real
estate without first obtaining a separate building permit for each such home
from the Office of the City Clerk. (1985 Code § 4-10)
   B.   Application For Permit: All applications for building permits shall be
signed and in writing, upon an official blank form supplied by the Office of
the City Clerk or the City building inspector, and shall be submitted to either
of said officials. (Ord. 313, 7-25-1989; amd. Ord. 423, 8-28-2018)
